sample_1.justification: The bundle references Starbucks' public waste-reduction goal (announced around 2019) and a 'Borrow a Cup' pilot (reported around 2020); a model needs knowledge through 2020 to avoid temporal leakage.

Starbucks waste-cut goal by 2030.search_query: When did Starbucks announce its goal to cut waste in half by 2030?
Starbucks waste-cut goal by 2030.evidence:
Starbucks announced its goal to reduce waste by 50% by 2030 on January 21, 2020. This commitment was part of a broader initiative to become a "resource-positive" company, aiming to store more carbon than it emits, eliminate waste, and provide more clean freshwater than it uses. ([stories.starbucks.com](https://stories.starbucks.com/emea/stories/2020/starbucks-announces-multi-decade-aspiration-to-become-resource-positive/?utm_source=openai))

To achieve this waste reduction target, Starbucks has implemented several strategies, including expanding plant-based menu options, shifting away from single-use packaging, and investing in sustainable farming and forest practices. ([foodbusinessnews.net](https://www.foodbusinessnews.net/articles/15257-starbucks-lays-out-2030-sustainability-targets?utm_source=openai))

In line with these efforts, Starbucks has also been working on redesigning its cups to reduce plastic usage. For instance, in April 2024, the company introduced new cold cups that use up to 20% less plastic, aiming to eliminate over 13.5 million pounds of plastic waste annually. ([apnews.com](https://apnews.com/article/90f19ce6ff721c7bf900f1447932dcc0?utm_source=openai))

Additionally, Starbucks has expanded its Greener Stores program, certifying over 3,500 stores globally by April 2023. These stores meet environmental standards across areas such as energy efficiency, water stewardship, and waste diversion, contributing to the company's waste reduction goals. ([about.starbucks.com](https://about.starbucks.com/press/2023/starbucks-verifies-3500-greener-stores-globally/?utm_source=openai))

Through these initiatives, Starbucks is actively working towards its 2030 target to halve waste and promote sustainability across its operations.


## Starbucks' Sustainability Initiatives and Cup Redesign:
- [Booming cold drink sales mean more plastic waste. So Starbucks redesigned its cups](https://apnews.com/article/90f19ce6ff721c7bf900f1447932dcc0?utm_source=openai), Published on Thursday, April 18
- [Citing sustainability, Starbucks wants to overhaul its iconic cup. Will customers go along?](https://apnews.com/article/5a3a5d7d4a66725f9747cbab23cb586d?utm_source=openai), Published on Thursday, September 14
- [Citing sustainability, Starbucks wants to overhaul its iconic cup. Will customers go along?](https://apnews.com/article/6c34423c98bf47b2a6049ae2cc43a3c1?utm_source=openai), Published on Thursday, September 14

Starbucks 'Borrow a Cup' pilot.search_query: When did Starbucks pilot or test a 'Borrow a Cup' reusable cup program?
Starbucks 'Borrow a Cup' pilot.evidence:
Starbucks initiated its "Borrow a Cup" reusable cup program with a pilot in five Seattle stores in April 2021. ([vendingmarketwatch.com](https://www.vendingmarketwatch.com/coffee-service/news/21217887/starbuckss-borrow-a-cup-program-tests-in-seattle-charges-1-deposit?utm_source=openai)) Customers could order beverages in reusable cups for a $1 refundable deposit, with the cups returned via contactless kiosks or through a local recycling service. The program aimed to reduce single-use cup waste and promote sustainability.

Following the Seattle trial, Starbucks expanded the "Borrow a Cup" program to other locations. In August 2023, the company launched a test in 12 stores in Napa and Petaluma, California, running from August 14 through October 22. ([about.starbucks.com](https://about.starbucks.com/press/2023/starbucks-latest-california-borrow-a-cup-test-furthers-companys-shift-toward-reusables/?utm_source=openai)) This initiative was part of Starbucks' broader commitment to sustainability and reducing waste.

Additionally, Starbucks has been testing reusable cup programs in other regions, including the United Kingdom, Japan, Singapore, and Taiwan, as part of its global efforts to promote reusable and recyclable packaging. ([yahoo.com](https://www.yahoo.com/news/starbucks-eyes-2025-transition-reusable-164543130.html?utm_source=openai))

For a visual overview of the "Borrow a Cup" program, you can watch the following video:

[New Test: Borrow a Cup, Save a Cup](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3Pn4UTaXNGw&utm_source=openai)

sample_2.justification: The Java answer uses Generics (List<Integer>), which were introduced in Java 5 (2004); the Collections Framework dates earlier but the generics requirement sets the cutoff.

Java Generics.search_query: When were generics introduced in Java (which release/year)?
Java Generics.evidence: Generics were introduced in Java with the release of J2SE 5.0, also known as Java 5, in 2004. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Generics_in_Java?utm_source=openai)) This addition allowed developers to write more flexible and reusable code while maintaining type safety. Prior to generics, collections in Java used `Object` as their element type, necessitating explicit casting and potentially leading to runtime errors. ([eecs.qmul.ac.uk](https://www.eecs.qmul.ac.uk/~mmh/AMCM048/furtherjava/generics.html?utm_source=openai))

Java Collections Framework.search_query: When was the Java Collections Framework introduced?
Java Collections Framework.evidence: The Java Collections Framework was introduced in JDK 1.2, released in 1998. ([cs.cmu.edu](https://www.cs.cmu.edu/~charlie/courses/17-214/2021-spring/slides/20210318-collections-design.pdf?utm_source=openai)) It was designed and developed primarily by Joshua Bloch. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Java_collections_framework?utm_source=openai)) This framework provides a unified architecture for representing and manipulating collections, enabling them to be manipulated independently of their representation details. ([docs.oracle.com](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/technotes/guides/collections/index.html?utm_source=openai))

Call of Duty franchise.search_query: When was the first Call of Duty game released?
Call of Duty franchise.evidence:
The first *Call of Duty* game was released on October 29, 2003, for Microsoft Windows. Developed by Infinity Ward and published by Activision, it is a first-person shooter that simulates infantry and combined arms warfare during World War II. The game offers multiple perspectives, including those of American, British, and Soviet soldiers. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Call_of_Duty_%28video_game%29?utm_source=openai))

Since then, the *Call of Duty* franchise has expanded significantly, with numerous sequels and spin-offs. The most recent installment, *Call of Duty: Black Ops 7*, was released on November 14, 2025. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Call_of_Duty%3A_Black_Ops_7?utm_source=openai))


## Recent Developments in the Call of Duty Franchise:
- [Yes, those leaks were true: Black Ops 7 is out this November, it's still coming to PS4 and Xbox One, and there's an open beta right around the corner](https://www.gamesradar.com/games/call-of-duty/call-of-duty-black-ops-7-release-date-open-beta-announced/?utm_source=openai), Published on Tuesday, August 19
- [Activision ditches back-to-back Modern Warfare or Black Ops releases after a weak Black Ops 7 launch](https://www.techradar.com/gaming/activision-ditches-back-to-back-modern-warfare-or-black-ops-releases-after-a-weak-black-ops-7-launch?utm_source=openai), Published on Wednesday, December 10
- [After Black Ops 7's weaker launch, Call of Duty will no longer do back-to-back releases in the same series](https://www.pcgamer.com/games/call-of-duty/after-black-ops-7s-weaker-launch-call-of-duty-will-no-longer-do-yearly-releases-in-the-same-series/?utm_source=openai), Published on Tuesday, December 09

Introduction of bullet drop in Call of D.search_query: When did bullet drop mechanics become notable in Call of Duty (e.g., Blackout)?
Introduction of bullet drop in Call of D.evidence:
Bullet drop mechanics became notable in the Call of Duty series with the introduction of the Blackout mode in *Call of Duty: Black Ops 4*, released in October 2018. Unlike traditional Call of Duty multiplayer modes that utilized hitscan mechanics—where bullets travel instantly to their target—Blackout incorporated projectile-based ballistics, requiring players to account for bullet travel time and drop over distance. ([dexerto.com](https://www.dexerto.com/call-of-duty/how-bullet-drop-works-call-duty-blackout-190359/?utm_source=openai))

This shift was highlighted during the game's development. In August 2018, Treyarch developer Tony Flame revealed that Blackout would feature "mixed ballistics," implementing bullet drop on certain weapons, meaning players would need to "lead" their targets while aiming. ([dexerto.com](https://www.dexerto.com/call-of-duty/treyarch-dev-reveals-bullet-drop-and-new-ballistics-system-will-be-tested-in-black-ops-4-multiplayer-beta-129626/?utm_source=openai))

The inclusion of bullet drop in Blackout marked a significant departure from the series' traditional mechanics, adding a layer of realism and strategic depth to long-range engagements.

For a detailed breakdown of bullet drop mechanics in Blackout, you might find this video helpful:

[Bullet Drop for ALL Guns in Blackout! (+ Extended Barrel & Suppressor Breakdown)](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ToOj0OP9D3Y&utm_source=openai)

Call of Duty: Warzone release.search_query: When was Call of Duty: Warzone released?
Call of Duty: Warzone release.evidence:
Call of Duty: Warzone was initially released on March 10, 2020, as a free-to-play battle royale game for PlayStation 4, Windows, and Xbox One. It was developed by Raven Software and Infinity Ward, and published by Activision. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Call_of_Duty%3A_Warzone?utm_source=openai))

A successor, initially titled Call of Duty: Warzone 2.0, was released on November 16, 2022. This version introduced new features and content, including a new map and game modes. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Call_of_Duty%3A_Warzone_%282022_video_game%29?utm_source=openai))

In March 2024, a mobile version of Warzone, titled Call of Duty: Warzone Mobile, was released for iOS and Android devices. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Call_of_Duty?utm_source=openai))

As of January 2026, the original Warzone servers were shut down on September 21, 2023, to focus development on Warzone 2.0. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Call_of_Duty%3A_Warzone?utm_source=openai))

For a visual overview of the game's launch, you can watch the Verdansk Launch Trailer below:

[Verdansk Launch Trailer | Call of Duty: Warzone](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pqPCFUUbMiU&utm_source=openai)

Mack Bolan (The Executioner).evidence: Mack Bolan, known as "The Executioner," first appeared in the novel *War Against the Mafia*, published in 1969. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mack_Bolan?utm_source=openai)) Created by author Don Pendleton, this series has since expanded to include numerous novels and spin-offs, making Bolan a prominent figure in action-adventure literature.

Sonic the Hedgehog (franchise).search_query: When was the first Sonic the Hedgehog game released?
Sonic the Hedgehog (franchise).evidence:
The first "Sonic the Hedgehog" game was released in 1991. It debuted in Japan on June 23, 1991, followed by releases in North America and Europe on June 21 and June 23, respectively. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sonic_the_Hedgehog_%281991_video_game%29?utm_source=openai))

This platform game introduced players to Sonic, a hedgehog capable of running at supersonic speeds, as he attempts to thwart the plans of the mad scientist Doctor Eggman. The game was developed by Sega's Sonic Team, with key contributors including designer Hirokazu Yasuhara, artist Naoto Ohshima, and programmer Yuji Naka. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sonic_the_Hedgehog_%281991_video_game%29?utm_source=openai))

The original "Sonic the Hedgehog" game was a significant success, selling over 40 million copies across all platforms and becoming one of the best-selling video games of its time. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sonic_the_Hedgehog_%281991_video_game%29?utm_source=openai))

For a visual experience of the game, you might enjoy watching the first part of the gameplay:

[Sonic the Hedgehog (Sega Genesis) - Part 1](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CqOlpQ7sepE&utm_source=openai)

Dr. Eggman (Dr. Robotnik).search_query: When did Dr. Eggman (Dr. Robotnik) first appear?
Dr. Eggman (Dr. Robotnik).evidence:
Dr. Eggman, also known as Dr. Ivo Robotnik, first appeared in the 1991 Sega Genesis game *Sonic the Hedgehog*. In this debut, he attempts to collect the Chaos Emeralds and transform the animals of South Island into robots. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Doctor_Eggman?utm_source=openai))

Prior to this, Eggman made a brief cameo in the 1991 TeraDrive game *Puzzle Construction*. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Doctor_Eggman?utm_source=openai))

In the United States, during the localization of *Sonic the Hedgehog*, Sega of America renamed the character Dr. Ivo Robotnik, while the Japanese version retained the name Dr. Eggman. Later games reconciled the different names by establishing "Robotnik" as his real name and "Eggman" as a nickname. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Doctor_Eggman?utm_source=openai))

Eggman has since become the primary antagonist in the *Sonic the Hedgehog* series, appearing in nearly every game and various other media.

For a visual depiction of Dr. Eggman's first defeat by Sonic, you might enjoy this clip from the *Sonic X* series:

[The first time Sonic owns Eggman | Sonic vs. Dr. Eggman | Sonic X (2003)](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7x64j5DtNs4&utm_source=openai)

Sonic X / Chris Thorndyke.search_query: When did the Sonic X anime first air and introduce Chris Thorndyke?
Sonic X / Chris Thorndyke.evidence:
"Sonic X," the anime series based on Sega's Sonic the Hedgehog franchise, first aired in Japan on April 6, 2003. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sonic_X?utm_source=openai)) The series introduces Chris Thorndyke, a 12-year-old boy who rescues Sonic after he falls into Chris's pool, in the very first episode titled "Sonic to the Rescue." ([sonic-x.fandom.com](https://sonic-x.fandom.com/wiki/Sonic_to_the_Rescue?utm_source=openai))

In the United States, "Sonic X" premiered on August 23, 2003, on the Fox Kids Network. ([rottentomatoes.com](https://www.rottentomatoes.com/tv/sonic_x?utm_source=openai)) Chris's introduction to American audiences occurred in the same episode, "Sonic to the Rescue," which aired on September 13, 2003. ([sonic-x.fandom.com](https://sonic-x.fandom.com/wiki/Sonic_to_the_Rescue?utm_source=openai))

For a visual reference, here's a clip from Episode 52 of "Sonic X," showcasing Chris Thorndyke as an 18-year-old:

[Chris Thorndyke as an 18-Year-Old in Sonic X Episode 52](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rcyyPCDP8oE&utm_source=openai)

Fate/stay night (Tohsaka Rin, Sakura Mat.evidence:
"Fate/stay night" is a Japanese visual novel developed by Type-Moon, first released on January 30, 2004. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fate/stay_night?utm_source=openai)) The game introduces several key characters, including Tohsaka Rin, Sakura Matou, and Illyasviel von Einzbern.

- **Tohsaka Rin**: A model student and secretly a mage, Rin is a central character in the "Unlimited Blade Works" route. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fate/stay_night?utm_source=openai))

- **Sakura Matou**: A quiet, soft-spoken girl and Shirou's longtime friend, Sakura plays a significant role in the "Heaven's Feel" route. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fate/stay_night?utm_source=openai))

- **Illyasviel von Einzbern**: A young girl with a mysterious background, Illyasviel is involved in the overarching narrative of the visual novel. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fate/stay_night?utm_source=openai))

These characters are integral to the game's multiple story routes, each offering a unique perspective on the events of the Holy Grail War.

Chloe von Einzbern (Fate/kaleid prismail.search_query: When did Fate/kaleid liner PRISMA ILLYA debut (introducing Chloe von Einzbern)?
Chloe von Einzbern (Fate/kaleid prismail.evidence:
Chloe von Einzbern, also known as Kuro, first appears in the "Fate/kaleid liner Prisma☆Illya" anime series during the second season, titled "Fate/kaleid liner Prisma☆Illya 2wei!" This season aired in Japan from July 10 to September 11, 2014. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fate/kaleid_liner_Prisma_Illya_2wei?utm_source=openai))

In the series, Chloe is introduced as a mysterious girl identical to Illyasviel von Einzbern, save for her dark skin, white hair, and golden eyes. She emerges after Illya and Miyu capture all the Class Cards, initially serving as an antagonistic presence with the goal of destroying Illya for reasons unknown. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fate/kaleid_liner_Prisma_Illya?utm_source=openai))

Chloe's character is later revealed to be another side of Illya that was previously sealed away, allowing Illya to live an ordinary life. This duality adds depth to the narrative, exploring themes of identity and self-acceptance. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fate/kaleid_liner_Prisma_Illya?utm_source=openai))

Reines El-Melloi Archisorte (Lord El-Mel.evidence:
Reines El-Melloi Archisorte is a character from "The Case Files of Lord El-Melloi II," a Japanese light novel series written by Makoto Sanda and illustrated by Mineji Sakamoto. The series began serialization on December 30, 2014, and concluded on May 17, 2019, with a total of 10 volumes. Reines is introduced as the true heir of the El-Melloi family. After the death of the previous Lord El-Melloi during the events of "Fate/Zero," she appoints Waver Velvet as her adoptive brother and steward to lead the family until she is of proper age to assume the title herself. For a visual introduction to Reines, you might find the following character trailer helpful:

Luvia Edelfelt (Fate universe character).search_query: When did Luvia Edelfelt first appear in the Fate franchise?
Luvia Edelfelt (Fate universe character).evidence:
Luviagelita Edelfelt, commonly known as Luvia, first appeared in the Fate franchise in the visual novel *Fate/hollow ataraxia*, released in 2005. In this game, she is introduced as a rival to Rin Tohsaka. ([typemoon.fandom.com](https://typemoon.fandom.com/wiki/Luviagelita_Edelfelt?utm_source=openai))

Following her debut, Luvia became a recurring character in various Fate-related media. She appears in the *Fate/kaleid liner Prisma☆Illya* series, where she is portrayed as a wealthy and proud young sorceress overseeing Miyu Edelfelt's activities. ([fateuniverse.fandom.com](https://fateuniverse.fandom.com/wiki/Luviageltia_Edelfelt_%28Fate/kaleid_Liner_Prisma_Illya%29?utm_source=openai)) Additionally, she is featured in *Fate/Unlimited Codes*, a 3D fighting game released in 2008, where she is depicted as a student at the Mage's Association academy, the Clock Tower. ([fightersgeneration.com](https://www.fightersgeneration.com/characters4/luviagelita.html?utm_source=openai))

Luvia's character is known for her rivalry with Rin Tohsaka, stemming from their mutual affection for Shirou Emiya. This rivalry has been a central theme in several Fate narratives, contributing to her prominence within the franchise.

Clock Tower / Clocktower Association of.search_query: When was the Clock Tower (Clocktower Association of magi) first introduced in the Fate series?
Clock Tower / Clocktower Association of.evidence:
The Clock Tower, the central hub of the Mage's Association in the Fate series, was established around 500 AD. This period marks the beginning of the Clock Tower as a significant center for magi. ([typemoon.fandom.com](https://typemoon.fandom.com/wiki/First_Magic?utm_source=openai))

In the Fate timeline, the Clock Tower's influence and prominence have been depicted in various works, including the light novel "Fate/Zero" (2006) and the anime adaptation "Fate/Apocrypha" (2017). Eggman has since become the primary antagonist in the *Sonic the Hedgehog* series, appearing in nearly every game and various other media adaptations.

([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Windows_Presentation_Foundation?utm_source=openai)) WPF, codenamed "Avalon," was developed to provide a unified framework for building rich user interfaces on Windows. XAML serves as the declarative markup language in WPF, allowing developers to define user interfaces in a clear and structured manner. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extensible_Application_Markup_Language?utm_source=openai))

.NET Framework 3.0.evidence:
The .NET Framework 3.0 was released on November 6, 2006. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/.NET_Framework_version_history?utm_source=openai)) This version introduced four major components:

- **Windows Presentation Foundation (WPF):** A new user interface subsystem and API based on XAML markup language, utilizing 3D computer graphics hardware and Direct3D technologies.

- **Windows Communication Foundation (WCF):** A service-oriented messaging system that allows programs to interoperate locally or remotely, similar to web services.

- **Windows Workflow Foundation (WF):** Enables building task automation and integrated transactions using workflows.

- **Windows CardSpace:** A software component that securely stores a person's digital identities and provides a unified interface for choosing the identity for a particular transaction, such as logging into a website.

These components were designed to enhance the development of Windows applications by providing advanced features for user interfaces, communication, workflows, and identity management.

WPF ComboBox control (including PART_Edi.search_query: When was the WPF ComboBox control with templating and PART_EditableTextBox introduced?
WPF ComboBox control (including PART_Edi.evidence:
The WPF ComboBox control, introduced with the .NET Framework 3.0 in 2006, includes the `PART_EditableTextBox` as part of its default ControlTemplate. This component allows the ComboBox to function in an editable mode, enabling users to type their own input in addition to selecting from the dropdown list. ([learn.microsoft.com](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/desktop/wpf/controls/combobox-styles-and-templates?utm_source=openai))

To make a ComboBox editable, you can set its `IsEditable` property to `true` in XAML:

```xml
<ComboBox IsEditable="True">
    <!-- ComboBox items here -->
</ComboBox>
```

This configuration allows users to enter custom text while still providing the option to select from predefined items. ([learnwpf.com](https://learnwpf.com/post/2006/07/11/How-can-I-allow-users-to-edit-text-in-a-ComboBox-in-WPF.aspx?utm_source=openai))

For more advanced customization, such as modifying the appearance or behavior of the editable portion, you can define a custom ControlTemplate that includes the `PART_EditableTextBox`. This approach provides greater flexibility in tailoring the ComboBox to specific requirements. ([learn.microsoft.com](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/desktop/wpf/controls/combobox-styles-and-templates?utm_source=openai))

WPF control parts (ToggleButton, Popup,.search_query: When were ToggleButton, Popup, and PART_EditableTextBox part names available in WPF?
WPF control parts (ToggleButton, Popup,.evidence:
In Windows Presentation Foundation (WPF), the `ToggleButton` control has been available since the initial release of WPF in 2006. The `Popup` control, which is commonly used in conjunction with `ToggleButton` to create dropdowns, has also been part of WPF since its inception.

Regarding the `PART_EditableTextBox` and `PART_Popup` part names, these are specific to the `ComboBox` control's `ControlTemplate`. The `PART_EditableTextBox` is a `TextBox` that contains the text of the `ComboBox`, and the `PART_Popup` is a `Popup` that displays the dropdown list of items. These part names have been part of WPF since at least 2010, as evidenced by their inclusion in the book "C# 2010 For Programmers" by Deitel & Deitel. ([informit.com](https://www.informit.com/content/images/9780132618205/samplepages/0132618206.pdf?utm_source=openai))

Therefore, all these controls and part names have been available in WPF since its early versions, with the `ToggleButton` and `Popup` controls being part of WPF from the beginning, and the `PART_EditableTextBox` and `PART_Popup` part names being part of the `ComboBox` control's template since at least 2010.

Starbucks waste-cut goal by 2030.search_query: When did Starbucks announce a goal to reduce waste by 50% by 2030?
Starbucks waste-cut goal by 2030.evidence:
Starbucks announced its goal to reduce waste by 50% by 2030 on January 21, 2020. In a public letter, CEO Kevin Johnson outlined the company's commitment to becoming "resource positive," aiming to store more carbon than it emits, eliminate waste, and provide more clean freshwater than it uses. The specific targets include a 50% reduction in waste sent to landfill from stores and manufacturing, driven by a broader shift toward a circular economy. ([stories.starbucks.com](https://stories.starbucks.com/emea/stories/2020/message-from-starbucks-ceo-kevin-johnson-starbucks-new-sustainability-commitment/?utm_source=openai))

To achieve this, Starbucks has implemented several initiatives, such as expanding plant-based menu options, shifting from single-use to reusable packaging, and investing in innovative agricultural practices and waste management. ([foodbusinessnews.net](https://www.foodbusinessnews.net/articles/15257-starbucks-lays-out-2030-sustainability-targets?utm_source=openai))

As of January 2024, Starbucks has further advanced its sustainability efforts by accepting reusable personal cups at all service points, including drive-thru and mobile orders, supporting the goal to cut waste by 50% by 2030. ([axios.com](https://www.axios.com/2024/01/03/starbucks-reusable-cup-policy-mobile-drive-thru?utm_source=openai))


## Starbucks' Sustainability Initiatives and Waste Reduction Efforts:
- [Starbucks reusable cups now accepted at drive-thru, mobile orders](https://www.axios.com/2024/01/03/starbucks-reusable-cup-policy-mobile-drive-thru?utm_source=openai), Published on Wednesday, January 03
- [Booming cold drink sales mean more plastic waste. So Starbucks redesigned its cups](https://apnews.com/article/90f19ce6ff721c7bf900f1447932dcc0?utm_source=openai), Published on Thursday, April 18
- [Citing sustainability, Starbucks wants to overhaul its iconic cup. Will customers go along?](https://apnews.com/article/5a3a5d7d4a66725f9747cbab23cb586d?utm_source=openai), Published on Thursday, September 14

Starbucks 'Borrow a Cup' pilot.search_query: When did Starbucks pilot a 'Borrow a Cup' or reusable-cup program?
Starbucks 'Borrow a Cup' pilot.evidence:
Starbucks initiated its "Borrow a Cup" program in March 2021 with a pilot in five Seattle stores. ([seattle.eater.com](https://seattle.eater.com/2021/4/7/22372019/starbucks-pilot-program-borrow-a-cup-starts-in-seattle?utm_source=openai)) This program allowed customers to borrow reusable cups for a $1 refundable deposit, aiming to reduce single-use cup waste. The pilot ran until May 31, 2021. ([foodnetwork.com](https://www.foodnetwork.com/fn-dish/news/starbucks-reusable-cup-program-borrow-a-cup-seattle?utm_source=openai))

Building on this success, Starbucks expanded the program to other locations:

- **Singapore**: Launched in January 2022 across three stores in the National University of Singapore, running until May 2022. ([stories.starbucks.com](https://stories.starbucks.com/asia/stories/2022/starbucks-launches-a-reusable-borrow-a-cup-program-at-three-stores-in-singapore/?utm_source=openai))

- **Taiwan**: Initiated in July 2022, with plans to extend to all stores nationwide by the end of 2023. ([stories.starbucks.com](https://stories.starbucks.com/asia/stories/2022/starbucks-offers-borrow-a-cup-program-at-sixty-stores-in-taiwan/?utm_source=openai))

- **California**: In August 2023, Starbucks expanded the program to 12 stores in Napa and Petaluma, offering customers the option to borrow a cup or bring their own reusable cup. ([about.starbucks.com](https://about.starbucks.com/press/2023/starbucks-latest-california-borrow-a-cup-test-furthers-companys-shift-toward-reusables/?utm_source=openai))

These initiatives reflect Starbucks' ongoing commitment to sustainability and reducing single-use cup waste.

Call of Duty franchise.search_query: When was the first Call of Duty game released?
Call of Duty franchise.evidence:
The first *Call of Duty* game was released on October 29, 2003, for Microsoft Windows. Developed by Infinity Ward and published by Activision, it is a first-person shooter that simulates infantry and combined arms warfare during World War II. The game offers multiple perspectives, including American, British, and Soviet campaigns in Europe. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Call_of_Duty_%28video_game%29?utm_source=openai))

Since then, the *Call of Duty* franchise has expanded significantly, with numerous sequels and spin-offs. The most recent installment, *Call of Duty: Black Ops 7*, was released on November 14, 2025. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Call_of_Duty%3A_Black_Ops_7?utm_source=openai))

Call of Duty: Warzone.search_query: When was Call of Duty: Warzone released?
Call of Duty: Warzone.evidence:
Call of Duty: Warzone was initially released on March 10, 2020, as a free-to-play battle royale game for PlayStation 4, Windows, and Xbox One. It was developed by Raven Software and Infinity Ward, and published by Activision. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Call_of_Duty%3A_Warzone?utm_source=openai))

A successor, initially titled Call of Duty: Warzone 2.0, was released on November 16, 2022. This version introduced new features and content, including a new map and game modes. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Call_of_Duty%3A_Warzone_%282022_video_game%29?utm_source=openai))

In March 2024, Call of Duty: Warzone Mobile was launched, bringing the Warzone experience to mobile devices. ([callofduty.com](https://www.callofduty.com/blog/2024/03/call-of-duty-warzone-mobile-prepare-for-launch-need-to-know.?utm_source=openai))

As of January 2026, the original Warzone servers were shut down on September 21, 2023, to focus development on Warzone 2.0. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Call_of_Duty%3A_Warzone?utm_source=openai))

For a visual overview of the game's launch, you can watch the Verdansk Launch Trailer below:

[Verdansk Launch Trailer | Call of Duty: Warzone](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pqPCFUUbMiU&utm_source=openai)

Prominent bullet-drop/long-range mechani.search_query: When did bullet drop and long-range sniping mechanics become prominent in modern Call of Duty modes (e.g., Blackout/Warzone)?
Prominent bullet-drop/long-range mechani.evidence:
Bullet drop and long-range sniping mechanics became prominent in Call of Duty's battle royale modes with the introduction of Blackout in 2018. Unlike previous titles that utilized hitscan mechanics—where bullets hit targets instantly without travel time—Blackout incorporated projectile ballistics, requiring players to account for bullet travel time and drop over distances. ([dexerto.com](https://www.dexerto.com/call-of-duty/how-bullet-drop-works-call-duty-blackout-190359/?utm_source=openai))

This emphasis on bullet drop continued with the release of Warzone in 2020. In Warzone, bullets generally tend to dip at ranges above 200 or 300 meters. Under 200 or 300 meters, players can line up their scope's reticle directly with the target, and the bullet will travel in a straight line. However, at distances over 300 meters, bullets start to dip in an arc-like fashion, necessitating players to aim slightly above the target to compensate for the drop. ([thegamer.com](https://www.thegamer.com/call-of-duty-warzone-bullet-drop-guide/?utm_source=openai))

In summary, the incorporation of bullet drop and long-range sniping mechanics became a defining feature of Call of Duty's battle royale modes starting with Blackout in 2018, continuing through Warzone in 2020.

Java Generics.search_query: When were generics introduced in Java?

([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Generics_in_Java?utm_source=openai)) This addition allowed developers to write more flexible and reusable code by enabling classes, interfaces, and methods to operate on objects of various types while providing compile-time type safety. java.util.Arrays / Arrays.asList.search_query: When was Arrays.asList introduced in Java?
java.util.Arrays / Arrays.asList.evidence:
The `Arrays.asList()` method was introduced in Java 1.2, released in December 1998. This method provides a way to convert an array into a fixed-size list backed by the original array. In Java 1.2, the method signature was:

```java
public static List asList(Object[] array)
```

With the introduction of generics in Java 5 (released in 2004), the method signature was updated to:

```java
public static <T> List<T> asList(T... a)
```

This change allowed for type-safe lists and enabled the use of varargs, making it more convenient to create lists from arrays. ([almaer.com](https://almaer.com/blog/jdk-15-arraysaslistrod-james-chris?utm_source=openai))

Volumetric 3D convolutional neural netwo.search_query: When were volumetric 3D convolutional neural networks for shape recognition (e.g., VoxNet, 3D ShapeNets) published?
Volumetric 3D convolutional neural netwo.evidence:
Volumetric 3D convolutional neural networks have significantly advanced shape recognition tasks. Notable models include 3D ShapeNets and VoxNet, both introduced in 2015.

**3D ShapeNets** was presented at the IEEE Conference on Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition (CVPR) in June 2015. ([gfx.cs.princeton.edu](https://gfx.cs.princeton.edu/pubs/Wu_2015_3SA/index.php?utm_source=openai)) This model represents 3D shapes as probability distributions over binary variables on a 3D voxel grid, utilizing a Convolutional Deep Belief Network to learn complex 3D shapes from raw CAD data.

**VoxNet** was introduced at the IEEE/RSJ International Conference on Intelligent Robots and Systems (IROS) in September 2015. ([ri.cmu.edu](https://www.ri.cmu.edu/publications/voxnet-a-3d-convolutional-neural-network-for-real-time-object-recognition/?utm_source=openai)) It integrates a volumetric occupancy grid representation with a supervised 3D Convolutional Neural Network, enabling real-time object recognition from 3D data.

These publications marked significant milestones in the application of 3D convolutional neural networks for shape recognition.

COVID-19 (SARS-CoV-2) first identified.search_query: When were the first cases of COVID-19 / SARS-CoV-2 identified?
COVID-19 (SARS-CoV-2) first identified.evidence:
The earliest known cases of COVID-19, caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus, were identified in Wuhan, China, in December 2019. The first officially reported case had a symptom onset on December 8, 2019. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19?utm_source=openai))

However, some studies suggest that the virus may have been circulating earlier. Research led by Dr. David Roberts at the University of Kent indicates that the first case likely arose between early October and mid-November 2019, with November 17 being the most probable date of origin. ([kent.ac.uk](https://www.kent.ac.uk/biosciences/news/2996/research-suggests-first-cases-of-covid-19-arose-earlier-than-initially-reported?utm_source=openai))

Additionally, reports from March 2020 indicated that Chinese government records showed the earliest case as early as November 17, 2019. ([theguardian.com](https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/mar/13/first-covid-19-case-happened-in-november-china-government-records-show-report?utm_source=openai))

These findings suggest that the virus may have been present in the community before the initial cases were officially recognized.

WHO declaration of COVID-19 as a pandemi.search_query: When did the World Health Organization declare COVID-19 a pandemic?
WHO declaration of COVID-19 as a pandemi.evidence:
The World Health Organization (WHO) declared COVID-19 a pandemic on March 11, 2020. ([upi.com](https://www.upi.com/Top_News/2022/03/11/On-This-Day-WHO-declares-COVID-19-a-pandemic/6561646842349/?utm_source=openai)) Prior to this, on January 30, 2020, the WHO had declared the outbreak a Public Health Emergency of International Concern (PHEIC). ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_health_emergency_of_international_concern?utm_source=openai))

The term "pandemic" refers to the global spread of a new disease, whereas a PHEIC is a formal declaration that an outbreak is a serious international public health concern. The declaration of a pandemic by the WHO is intended to signal the severity and global impact of the disease, prompting countries to take coordinated action.

For more details on the WHO's declaration of COVID-19 as a pandemic, you can watch the following video:

[WHO declares COVID-19 a global pandemic](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xKPWngYf2Wk&utm_source=openai)

The World Health Organization (WHO) convened a study to investigate the origins of SARS-CoV-2, the virus responsible for the COVID-19 pandemic. sample_3.justification: The Munich Agreement and the designation 'Sudetenland' date to 1938. Because the event predates 2001, the minimum safe cutoff per instructions is 2001 to avoid temporal leakage.

Munich Agreement (signing).search_query: When was the Munich Agreement signed?
Munich Agreement (signing).evidence:
The Munich Agreement was signed on September 30, 1938, in Munich, Germany. This accord permitted Nazi Germany's annexation of the Sudetenland region from Czechoslovakia, a move that was intended to appease Adolf Hitler and prevent further conflict in Europe. ([history.com](https://www.history.com/this-day-in-history/munich-pact-signed?utm_source=openai))

The agreement was signed by British Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain, French Prime Minister Édouard Daladier, German Chancellor Adolf Hitler, and Italian Prime Minister Benito Mussolini. The Czechoslovak government was not included in the negotiations, and the Sudetenland was occupied by German troops between October 1 and 10, 1938. ([encyclopedia.ushmm.org](https://encyclopedia.ushmm.org/content/en/timeline-event/holocaust/1933-1938/munich-agreement?utm_source=openai))

The Munich Agreement is often cited as a classic example of the policy of appeasement, where concessions were made to an aggressive power in hopes of avoiding war. However, this policy ultimately failed to prevent the outbreak of World War II. ([britannica.com](https://www.britannica.com/event/Munich-Agreement?utm_source=openai))


## Today in History: Munich Agreement Signed:
- [Today in History: September 29, Munich agreement established, aimed at appeasing Hitler](https://apnews.com/article/472455c0af92ceac00f1af64255cbcf7?utm_source=openai), Published on Sunday, September 10

Sudetenland (term applied in Munich Agre.search_query: When was the term 'Sudetenland' used in relation to the Munich Agreement?
Sudetenland (term applied in Munich Agre.evidence:
The term "Sudetenland" was used in relation to the Munich Agreement, signed on September 30, 1938, to refer to the predominantly German-speaking border regions of Czechoslovakia. The agreement permitted Nazi Germany to annex these areas, which were home to about three million ethnic Germans. ([britannica.com](https://www.britannica.com/event/Munich-Agreement?utm_source=openai))

The Sudetenland had been a focal point of tension due to the demands of the Sudeten German Party (SdP), led by Konrad Henlein, for greater autonomy and alignment with Germany. This agitation contributed to the escalation of the crisis that led to the Munich Agreement. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sudeten_Germans?utm_source=openai))

Following the agreement, German troops occupied the Sudetenland between October 1 and 10, 1938, effectively dissolving Czechoslovakia's defensive border fortifications and leading to significant political and economic consequences for the country. ([encyclopedia.ushmm.org](https://encyclopedia.ushmm.org/content/en/timeline-event/holocaust/1933-1938/munich-agreement?utm_source=openai))

Starbucks waste-cut goal by 2030.search_query: When did Starbucks announce a goal to cut waste by 50% by 2030?
Starbucks waste-cut goal by 2030.evidence:
Starbucks announced its goal to reduce waste sent to landfills by 50% by 2030 on January 21, 2020. This commitment was part of a broader initiative to become a "resource-positive" company, aiming to store more carbon than it emits, eliminate waste, and provide more clean freshwater than it uses. ([stories.starbucks.com](https://stories.starbucks.com/emea/stories/2020/message-from-starbucks-ceo-kevin-johnson-starbucks-new-sustainability-commitment/?utm_source=openai))

To achieve this waste reduction target, Starbucks outlined several strategies, including expanding plant-based menu options, shifting from single-use to reusable packaging, and investing in innovative waste management practices. ([foodbusinessnews.net](https://www.foodbusinessnews.net/articles/15257-starbucks-lays-out-2030-sustainability-targets?utm_source=openai))

In March 2023, Starbucks further demonstrated its commitment by announcing over $50 million in planned investments to advance its sustainability targets, focusing on cutting its water and waste footprints in half by 2030. ([about.starbucks.com](https://about.starbucks.com/press/2023/starbucks-commits-over-50-million-to-sustainable-waste-and-water-funds-toward-a-resource-positive-future/?utm_source=openai))

These efforts reflect Starbucks' ongoing dedication to environmental sustainability and its goal of becoming a resource-positive company by 2030.

Starbucks 'Borrow a Cup' pilot.evidence:
Starbucks initiated its "Borrow a Cup" reusable cup program in March 2021 with a pilot in five Seattle stores. ([seattle.eater.com](https://seattle.eater.com/2021/4/7/22372019/starbucks-pilot-program-borrow-a-cup-starts-in-seattle?utm_source=openai)) This program allowed customers to order beverages in reusable cups, paying a $1 refundable deposit, and return them via contactless kiosks or through a local recycling service. ([vendingmarketwatch.com](https://www.vendingmarketwatch.com/coffee-service/news/21217887/starbuckss-borrow-a-cup-program-tests-in-seattle-charges-1-deposit?utm_source=openai))

Building on this success, Starbucks expanded the program to other locations, including a 12-store pilot in Napa and Petaluma, California, from August 14 to October 22, 2023. ([about.starbucks.com](https://about.starbucks.com/press/2023/starbucks-latest-california-borrow-a-cup-test-furthers-companys-shift-toward-reusables/?utm_source=openai)) Additionally, the program was introduced in Singapore across three stores from January to May 2022. These initiatives are part of Starbucks' broader commitment to sustainability, aiming to reduce waste by 50% by 2030. ([content-prod-live.cert.starbucks.com](https://content-prod-live.cert.starbucks.com/binary/v2/asset/137-83561.pdf?utm_source=openai))

Introduction of bullet drop in Call of D.evidence:
Bullet drop became a prominent mechanic in Call of Duty during the Blackout era, introduced with the release of Call of Duty: Black Ops 4 in 2018. Prior to this, the series primarily utilized a hitscan system, where bullets traveled instantly to their targets without considering travel time or gravity's effect.

In Blackout, Treyarch implemented a mixed ballistics system, making bullets act as projectiles that travel at a certain speed and drop over distance. This change required players to adjust their aim for long-range engagements, leading shots ahead of moving targets and aiming higher to compensate for bullet drop. ([dexerto.com](https://www.dexerto.com/call-of-duty/how-bullet-drop-works-call-duty-blackout-190359/?utm_source=openai))

The introduction of bullet drop in Blackout was part of a broader effort to enhance realism and strategic depth in the game. This mechanic was further refined in subsequent titles, such as Call of Duty: Modern Warfare (2019), where Infinity Ward incorporated bullet trajectory considerations into the campaign, requiring players to account for bullet drop and windage in long-range shots. ([dexerto.com](https://www.dexerto.com/call-of-duty/call-of-duty-dev-reveals-how-bullet-drop-will-work-modern-warfare-710625/?utm_source=openai))

In summary, bullet drop became a significant mechanic in Call of Duty starting with the Blackout mode in 2018, marking a shift from the traditional hitscan system to a more realistic projectile-based shooting experience.

Bash array append operator (iops+=) / ar.search_query: When was array append (+=) and the modern indexed array syntax introduced or supported in Bash?
Bash array append operator (iops+=) / ar.evidence:
In Bash, the `+=` operator for appending elements to arrays and the modern indexed array syntax were introduced in different versions:

- **Indexed Array Syntax**: Bash has supported indexed arrays for a long time. You can create an indexed array by assigning values to a variable using parentheses:

  ```bash
  my_array=(value1 value2 value3)
  ```

  This syntax has been available since early versions of Bash. ([gnu.org](https://www.gnu.org/s/bash/manual/html_node/Arrays.html?utm_source=openai))

- **Array Append Operator (`+=`)**: The `+=` operator for appending elements to arrays was introduced in Bash version 4.3, released in 2015. This operator allows you to add elements to an existing array without specifying an index:

  ```bash
  my_array+=(new_element)
  ```

  This feature simplifies array manipulation by enabling dynamic addition of elements. ([gnu.org](https://www.gnu.org/s/bash/manual/html_node/Arrays.html?utm_source=openai))

Therefore, while the modern indexed array syntax has been part of Bash for a long time, the `+=` operator for appending elements was introduced in Bash version 4.3.

Morgan silver dollar (first minted).search_query: In what year was the first Morgan silver dollar minted?
Morgan silver dollar (first minted).evidence:
The first Morgan silver dollar was minted in 1878. This coin was designed by George T. Morgan and was produced to stabilize the silver market. The initial production took place at the Philadelphia Mint, with the first acceptable strike occurring on March 11, 1878. The first minted Morgan dollar was presented to President Rutherford B. Hayes. ([americanmint.com](https://www.americanmint.com/1878-1921-silver-morgan-dollar-us-2420113?utm_source=openai))

The Morgan dollar was minted from 1878 to 1904, with a brief resumption in 1921. In 2021, the U.S. Mint revived the series, releasing new 99.9% fine Morgan silver dollars to commemorate the centennial anniversary of the last official minting. ([govmint.com](https://www.govmint.com/learn/post/what-years-were-morgan-silver-dollars-minted?utm_source=openai))

The coin features Liberty on the obverse and a heraldic eagle on the reverse, both designed by George T. Morgan. It was minted at various facilities, including Philadelphia, San Francisco, New Orleans, Carson City, and Denver. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Morgan_dollar?utm_source=openai))

The Morgan silver dollar remains a significant piece of American numismatic history, symbolizing the nation's westward expansion and industrial development in the late 19th century.

Coinage Act of 1873.search_query: When was the Coinage Act that ended free coining of silver enacted?
Coinage Act of 1873.evidence:
The Coinage Act of 1873, enacted on February 12, 1873, effectively ended the free coinage of silver in the United States. This legislation discontinued the practice of allowing holders of silver bullion to have it coined into standard silver dollars, thereby transitioning the U.S. monetary system toward a de facto gold standard. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coinage_Act_of_1873?utm_source=openai))

The act's passage was relatively quiet, with little public attention at the time. However, in 1876, when silver prices declined, silver producers attempted to bring silver bullion to the Mint, only to discover that the Mint was no longer authorized to coin it. This led to significant political controversy, with critics referring to the act as the "Crime of 1873." ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coinage_Act_of_1873?utm_source=openai))

It's important to note that while the Coinage Act of 1873 ended the free coinage of silver, it did not immediately eliminate silver coinage. The Mint continued to produce silver coins, such as the Trade dollar, until the Coinage Act of 1878, which authorized the resumption of silver coinage. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coinage_Act_of_1873?utm_source=openai))

Optical levitation / single-beam optical.search_query: When did Arthur Ashkin first demonstrate optical levitation or single-beam optical trapping (optical tweezers)?
Optical levitation / single-beam optical.evidence:
Arthur Ashkin first demonstrated optical levitation and single-beam optical trapping, now known as optical tweezers, in 1970. In that year, he published a paper in *Physical Review Letters* detailing his observations of optical forces on small dielectric particles. He demonstrated that a tightly focused laser beam could trap and manipulate microscopic particles, such as transparent glass spheres, by drawing them toward the beam's center. ([britannica.com](https://www.britannica.com/biography/Arthur-Ashkin?utm_source=openai))

In 1986, Ashkin and his colleagues advanced this technique by developing a single-beam gradient force optical trap, which became known as optical tweezers. This innovation allowed for the manipulation of biological particles, including viruses and bacteria, without causing damage, thereby opening new avenues in biological research. ([britannica.com](https://www.britannica.com/biography/Arthur-Ashkin?utm_source=openai))

For his groundbreaking work in optical trapping, Ashkin was awarded the Nobel Prize in Physics in 2018. ([aps.org](https://www.aps.org/about/news/2018/10/laser-tweezers-ultrashort-2018-nobel?utm_source=openai))

BIB002 / Li et al. measurement of instan.evidence: The paper by Li et al., titled "Measurement of the Instantaneous Velocity of a Brownian Particle," was published in the journal *Science* in 2010. ([chaos.utexas.edu](https://chaos.utexas.edu/publications/measurement-of-the-instantaneous-velocity-of-a-brownian-particle?utm_source=openai)) In this study, the researchers successfully measured the instantaneous velocity of a micrometer-sized glass bead held in air by an optical tweezer, providing direct verification of the energy equipartition theorem for a Brownian particle. They observed the transition from ballistic to diffusive regimes in Brownian motion and discussed potential applications of these methods toward cooling the center-of-mass motion of a bead in vacuum to the quantum ground motional state. ([pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/20488989/?utm_source=openai))

BIB001 / early levitation of glass spher.search_query: When were early experiments demonstrating levitation of dielectric spheres by radiation pressure published?
BIB001 / early levitation of glass spher.evidence:
The first experimental demonstration of levitating dielectric spheres using radiation pressure was published in 1971 by Arthur Ashkin and J.M. Dziedzic. Their study, titled "Optical Levitation by Radiation Pressure," was published in *Applied Physics Letters*. ([bohrium.com](https://www.bohrium.com/paper-details/optical-levitation-by-radiation-pressure/812368652471894016-535?utm_source=openai))

In this groundbreaking work, Ashkin and Dziedzic successfully levitated transparent glass spheres in both air and vacuum by utilizing the radiation pressure from laser light. They employed a single, vertically directed focused continuous-wave (cw) laser beam to suspend the spheres above a glass plate, demonstrating the feasibility of optical levitation through radiation pressure.

This pioneering experiment laid the foundation for subsequent advancements in optical trapping and manipulation of small particles, leading to the development of optical tweezers and various applications in physics, biology, and nanotechnology.

BIB001 / early levitation of glass spher.evidence:
The first experimental demonstration of levitating dielectric spheres using radiation pressure was conducted by Arthur Ashkin in 1969. He focused a continuous-wave argon laser beam onto a micron-sized latex sphere suspended in water, observing that the light's momentum could counteract gravity, causing the sphere to levitate. ([physicstoday.aip.org](https://physicstoday.aip.org/news/father-of-optical-trapping-awarded-a-share-of-the-nobel-prize-in-physics?utm_source=openai))

He discovered that the sphere was not only accelerated in the direction of the light beam due to scattering forces but was also drawn toward the beam's center. This phenomenon was explained by the gradient force, where the sphere's surface acted as a lens, bending the light and altering its momentum, thereby pulling the particle toward the higher-intensity center of the beam. ([physicstoday.aip.org](https://physicstoday.aip.org/news/father-of-optical-trapping-awarded-a-share-of-the-nobel-prize-in-physics?utm_source=openai))

sample_1.justification: The answer bundle references Starbucks' goal to cut waste by 2030 and a 'Borrow a Cup' pilot; those initiatives were publicized around 2019–2020, so a model needs knowledge through 2020 to avoid temporal leakage.

Starbucks waste-cut goal by 2030.search_query: When did Starbucks announce its goal to cut waste in half by 2030?
Starbucks waste-cut goal by 2030.evidence:
Starbucks announced its goal to reduce waste sent to landfills by 50% by 2030 on January 21, 2020. This commitment was part of a broader initiative to become a "resource-positive" company, aiming to store more carbon than it emits, eliminate waste, and provide more clean freshwater than it uses. ([stories.starbucks.com](https://stories.starbucks.com/emea/stories/2020/starbucks-announces-multi-decade-aspiration-to-become-resource-positive/?utm_source=openai))

To achieve this target, Starbucks outlined several strategies, including expanding plant-based menu options, shifting away from single-use packaging, and investing in sustainable agricultural practices and waste management. ([stories.starbucks.com](https://stories.starbucks.com/emea/stories/2020/5-things-to-know-about-starbucks-new-environmental-sustainability-commitment?utm_source=openai))

In subsequent years, Starbucks has made significant progress toward this goal. By April 2023, the company had certified 3,508 Greener Stores globally, expanding the program to 20 markets. ([about.starbucks.com](https://about.starbucks.com/press/2023/starbucks-verifies-3500-greener-stores-globally/?utm_source=openai)) Additionally, in March 2024, Starbucks announced the verification of 6,091 Greener Stores worldwide, nearly doubling its portfolio in the past year. ([about.starbucks.com](https://about.starbucks.com/press/2024/starbucks-announces-6000-greener-stores-worldwide/?utm_source=openai))

These efforts reflect Starbucks' ongoing commitment to sustainability and its ambitious goal of reducing waste by 50% by 2030.


## Starbucks' Sustainability Initiatives and Progress:
- [Starbucks reusable cups now accepted at drive-thru, mobile orders](https://www.axios.com/2024/01/03/starbucks-reusable-cup-policy-mobile-drive-thru?utm_source=openai), Published on Wednesday, January 03
- [Booming cold drink sales mean more plastic waste. So Starbucks redesigned its cups](https://apnews.com/article/90f19ce6ff721c7bf900f1447932dcc0?utm_source=openai), Published on Thursday, April 18
- [Citing sustainability, Starbucks wants to overhaul its iconic cup. Will customers go along?](https://apnews.com/article/5a3a5d7d4a66725f9747cbab23cb586d?utm_source=openai), Published on Thursday, September 14

Starbucks 'Borrow a Cup' pilot.search_query: When did Starbucks pilot a 'Borrow a Cup' reusable cup program?
Starbucks 'Borrow a Cup' pilot.evidence:
Starbucks initiated its "Borrow a Cup" reusable cup program in March 2021, piloting it at five stores in Seattle, Washington. ([seattle.eater.com](https://seattle.eater.com/2021/4/7/22372019/starbucks-pilot-program-borrow-a-cup-starts-in-seattle?utm_source=openai)) This program allowed customers to order beverages in reusable cups, paying a $1 refundable deposit, and return them via contactless kiosks or through a local recycling service. ([vendingmarketwatch.com](https://www.vendingmarketwatch.com/coffee-service/news/21217887/starbuckss-borrow-a-cup-program-tests-in-seattle-charges-1-deposit?utm_source=openai))

Following the Seattle pilot, Starbucks expanded the program to other locations. In January 2022, the company launched the "Borrow a Cup" program at three stores in Singapore, aiming to encourage customers to shift away from single-use cups. ([stories.starbucks.com](https://stories.starbucks.com/asia/stories/2022/starbucks-launches-a-reusable-borrow-a-cup-program-at-three-stores-in-singapore/?utm_source=openai)) By November 2022, the program had been implemented across 60 stores in Taiwan, with plans to extend to all stores nationwide by the end of 2023. ([stories.starbucks.com](https://stories.starbucks.com/asia/stories/2022/starbucks-offers-borrow-a-cup-program-at-sixty-stores-in-taiwan/?utm_source=openai))

In the United States, Starbucks continued to test the program in various locations. In August 2023, the company launched a reusable cup test in 12 stores in Napa and Petaluma, California, running from August 14 through October 22, 2023. ([about.starbucks.com](https://about.starbucks.com/press/2023/starbucks-latest-california-borrow-a-cup-test-furthers-companys-shift-toward-reusables/?utm_source=openai)) Additionally, Starbucks has been working towards offering customers the option to use their own personal reusable cups for every visit by the end of 2023. ([content-prod-live.cert.starbucks.com](https://content-prod-live.cert.starbucks.com/binary/v2/asset/137-88662.pdf?utm_source=openai))

These initiatives are part of Starbucks' broader commitment to sustainability and reducing waste, with the goal of achieving a 50% reduction in waste sent to landfills by 2030. ([content-prod-live.cert.starbucks.com](https://content-prod-live.cert.starbucks.com/binary/v2/asset/137-83561.pdf?utm_source=openai))

Java Generics.search_query: When were generics introduced in Java (J2SE)?
Java Generics.evidence: Generics were introduced in Java with the release of Java 5 (also known as J2SE 5.0) in 2004. This major update added generics to the language, allowing developers to write more type-safe and reusable code by specifying the types of objects that collections can contain.

Java Collections Framework.search_query: When was the Java Collections Framework introduced?
Java Collections Framework.evidence: The Java Collections Framework was introduced in JDK 1.2, released in 1998. ([cs.cmu.edu](https://www.cs.cmu.edu/~charlie/courses/17-214/2021-spring/slides/20210318-collections-design.pdf?utm_source=openai)) It was designed and developed primarily by Joshua Bloch. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Java_collections_framework?utm_source=openai)) This framework provides a unified architecture for representing and manipulating collections, enabling them to be manipulated independently of their representation details. ([docs.oracle.com](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/technotes/guides/collections/index.html?utm_source=openai))

The game is notable for presenting multiple viewpoints from the American, British, and Soviet campaigns in Europe. Call of Duty: Warzone.search_query: When was Call of Duty: Warzone released?
Call of Duty: Warzone.evidence:
Call of Duty: Warzone was initially released on March 10, 2020, as a free-to-play battle royale game for PlayStation 4, Windows, and Xbox One. It was developed by Raven Software and Infinity Ward, and published by Activision. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Call_of_Duty%3A_Warzone?utm_source=openai))

A successor, initially titled Call of Duty: Warzone 2.0, was released on November 16, 2022, as part of Call of Duty: Modern Warfare II. This version introduced new features and a new map, Al Mazrah. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Call_of_Duty%3A_Warzone_%282022_video_game%29?utm_source=openai))

In March 2024, Call of Duty: Warzone Mobile was launched, bringing the battle royale experience to mobile devices. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Call_of_Duty?utm_source=openai))

Introduction of bullet drop in Call of D.search_query: When did bullet drop mechanics become prominent in Call of Duty multiplayer or battle royale modes?
Introduction of bullet drop in Call of D.evidence:
Bullet drop mechanics became prominent in Call of Duty's multiplayer and battle royale modes starting with **Call of Duty: Black Ops 4**, released in October 2018. In this installment, the "Blackout" battle royale mode introduced bullet drop, requiring players to adjust their aim for long-range shots. Treyarch developer Tony Flame confirmed that this feature would be tested in the Black Ops 4 Multiplayer Beta. ([dexerto.com](https://www.dexerto.com/call-of-duty/treyarch-dev-reveals-bullet-drop-and-new-ballistics-system-will-be-tested-in-black-ops-4-multiplayer-beta-129626/?utm_source=openai))

Prior to Black Ops 4, the series primarily utilized a hitscan system, where bullets traveled instantly to their targets without considering travel time or drop. However, bullet drop was present in the campaign mode of earlier titles. For example, in the "All Ghillied Up" mission of the original Modern Warfare, players had to account for bullet drop and wind speed when taking a long-range shot. ([dexerto.com](https://www.dexerto.com/call-of-duty/call-of-duty-dev-reveals-how-bullet-drop-will-work-modern-warfare-710625/?utm_source=openai))

Following Black Ops 4, bullet drop mechanics continued to be a feature in subsequent titles. In **Call of Duty: Warzone**, released in March 2020, bullet drop was incorporated, affecting weapons differently based on their range and type. For instance, sniper rifles experienced minimal drop, while assault rifles and SMGs had more pronounced drop at longer distances. ([gamerevolution.com](https://www.gamerevolution.com/guides/640029-does-warzone-have-bullet-drop?utm_source=openai))

In summary, bullet drop mechanics became a significant aspect of Call of Duty's multiplayer and battle royale modes with the release of Black Ops 4 in 2018, marking a shift from the previous hitscan system.

Starbucks waste-cut goal by 2030.evidence:

In a public letter, CEO Kevin Johnson outlined the company's commitment to becoming "resource positive," aiming to store more carbon than it emits, eliminate waste, and provide more clean freshwater than it uses. The preliminary targets for 2030 included a 50% reduction in waste sent to landfills from stores and manufacturing. ([stories.starbucks.com](https://stories.starbucks.com/emea/stories/2020/starbucks-announces-multi-decade-aspiration-to-become-resource-positive/?utm_source=openai))

This initiative is part of Starbucks' broader sustainability efforts, which also encompass reducing carbon emissions and conserving water. The company has been working on various strategies to achieve these goals, such as expanding plant-based menu options, shifting away from single-use packaging, and investing in sustainable farming and forest practices. ([foodbusinessnews.net](https://www.foodbusinessnews.net/articles/15257-starbucks-lays-out-2030-sustainability-targets?utm_source=openai))

In subsequent years, Starbucks has continued to implement and refine these strategies, including piloting programs to reduce single-use cup usage and introducing redesigned cold cups to decrease plastic waste. ([apnews.com](https://apnews.com/article/5a3a5d7d4a66725f9747cbab23cb586d?utm_source=openai))

Ancient Egypt (sarcophagi).search_query: When did Ancient Egyptian civilization begin and when were sarcophagi first used?
Ancient Egypt (sarcophagi).evidence:
Ancient Egyptian civilization is generally considered to have begun around 3100 BCE, with the unification of Upper and Lower Egypt under the first pharaoh, Narmer (also known as Menes). ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_Dynasty_of_Egypt?utm_source=openai))

The earliest stone sarcophagi in Egypt date back to the 3rd Dynasty (c. 2650–2575 BCE). These early sarcophagi were designed to resemble mud-brick palaces, featuring ornamental false doors and windows. ([britannica.com](https://www.britannica.com/topic/sarcophagus?utm_source=openai))

Over time, the design and materials of sarcophagi evolved. By the 11th Dynasty (c. 2081–c. 1991 BCE), boxlike sarcophagi made of wood or limestone were in use. The 17th Dynasty (c. 1630–1540 BCE) saw the introduction of anthropoid coffins, shaped to resemble the human form with carved portrait heads. In the 18th–20th Dynasties (c. 1539–1075 BCE), the practice of enclosing inner coffins within stone outer sarcophagi became common, a tradition that continued into the Ptolemaic period. ([britannica.com](https://www.britannica.com/topic/sarcophagus?utm_source=openai))

For a visual overview of ancient Egyptian sarcophagi, you might find this video informative:

19th century (cast iron/lead-lined caske.search_query: When did cast iron and lead-lined coffins/caskets come into use in the 19th century?
19th century (cast iron/lead-lined caske.evidence:
In the 19th century, cast iron and lead-lined coffins became prominent, particularly among the affluent, due to their durability and preservation qualities.

**Cast Iron Coffins:**

In 1848, Almond Dunbar Fisk patented the first cast iron coffin, known as the "Fisk Metallic Burial Case." These coffins were designed to be airtight and waterproof, preserving the body and deterring grave robbers. They featured sculpted designs and glass viewing plates, allowing mourners to view the deceased without exposure to odors or pathogens. Fisk's coffins gained popularity among wealthier families, with prices significantly higher than traditional wooden coffins. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fisk_metallic_burial_case?utm_source=openai))

**Lead-Lined Coffins:**

Lead coffins, often used as inner linings within wooden coffins, became more common in the early 19th century. By the 1810s, some parishes and cemeteries required the use of lead coffins for interment in vaults, aiming to contain the decomposition process and prevent odors. However, the high cost of lead limited its widespread use. In 1840, the parish of St. Mary Woolnorth charged an extra £2 for burial in lead, indicating its exclusivity. ([discovery.ucl.ac.uk](https://discovery.ucl.ac.uk/10095497/7/Hoile_10095497_Thesis.pdf?utm_source=openai))

In summary, cast iron coffins were introduced in 1848 and gained popularity in the mid-19th century, while lead-lined coffins became more common in the early 19th century, particularly among the wealthy.

Middle Ages (European coffins).evidence:
The Middle Ages in Europe, also known as the medieval period, spanned approximately from the 5th to the late 15th century, beginning around 500 CE and ending around 1500 CE. ([britannica.com](https://www.britannica.com/topic/history-of-Europe/The-Middle-Ages?utm_source=openai)) This era is traditionally divided into three phases:

- **Early Middle Ages (c. 500–1000 CE):** Following the fall of the Western Roman Empire, this period was marked by the establishment of new kingdoms and the spread of Christianity.

- **High Middle Ages (c. 1000–1300 CE):** Characterized by population growth, economic expansion, and the rise of powerful monarchies.

- **Late Middle Ages (c. 1300–1500 CE):** A time of crisis due to events like the Black Death, leading to significant social and economic upheaval.

The exact dates marking the beginning and end of the Middle Ages can vary depending on regional histories and scholarly interpretations. Some historians propose different timeframes, such as 1000 to 1800 CE, or even from late antiquity through the 16th century. ([britannica.com](https://www.britannica.com/topic/history-of-Europe/The-Middle-Ages?utm_source=openai))

18th century (refinement and cabinetmaki.search_query: What century is the 18th century and when did cabinetmaking styles influence decorative furniture?
18th century (refinement and cabinetmaki.evidence:
The 18th century spanned from January 1, 1701, to December 31, 1800. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/18th_century?utm_source=openai))

During this period, cabinetmaking styles significantly influenced decorative furniture, particularly through the Rococo and Neoclassical movements. In the early 18th century, Rococo introduced ornate and intricate designs, characterized by naturalistic motifs like vines and plant tendrils. This style was evident in wood carvings on furniture pieces such as chairs, settees, and mirror frames. ([britannica.com](https://www.britannica.com/technology/furniture/Stylistic-and-decorative-processes-and-techniques?utm_source=openai))

Later in the century, the Neoclassical style emerged, emphasizing simplicity and classical references. This movement led to the development of the Gustavian style in Sweden, which blended French Neoclassicism with local design elements, resulting in restrained decoration and symmetrical proportions. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gustavian_style?utm_source=openai))

Additionally, the Chinoiserie trend brought Chinese-inspired designs into European furniture, incorporating motifs like pagodas and dragons, and introducing lacquer techniques that added glossy finishes to furniture pieces. ([cabinetmakers.co](https://www.cabinetmakers.co/famous-cabinet-makers-icons-of-craftsmanship-and-design/?utm_source=openai))

These evolving cabinetmaking styles throughout the 18th century had a profound impact on decorative furniture, shaping its aesthetics and craftsmanship.

19th century (industrial materials like.search_query: When were cast iron and lead-lined caskets used in the 19th century?
19th century (industrial materials like.evidence:
In the 19th century, cast iron and lead-lined caskets were primarily used for their durability and preservation qualities.

**Cast Iron Caskets:**

Introduced in 1848 by Almond D. Fisk, cast iron caskets gained popularity among wealthier families during the mid-19th century. These airtight caskets were designed to deter grave robbers and preserve the body, especially for individuals who died far from home and needed to be transported for burial. The caskets often featured sculpted designs and glass windows for viewing the deceased. By the 1850s, manufacturers like Crane, Breed, and Company of Cincinnati were producing these caskets, which were advertised to present the dead in an "undisturbed repose." ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fisk_metallic_burial_case?utm_source=openai))

**Lead-Lined Caskets:**

Lead-lined coffins were used to preserve the body and prevent decomposition. The use of lead coffins dates back to at least the early 19th century. For example, a lead coffin from 1846 was discovered in Leicester Cathedral, indicating their use during that period. ([leicestercathedral.org](https://leicestercathedral.org/ulas-lead-coffin?utm_source=openai))

In summary, both cast iron and lead-lined caskets were utilized in the 19th century, with cast iron caskets becoming more prevalent in the mid-1800s and lead-lined coffins being used earlier in the century.

Industrial Revolution (manufacturing eff.search_query: When did the Industrial Revolution begin and how did it change manufacturing practices?
Industrial Revolution (manufacturing eff.evidence:
The Industrial Revolution began in Great Britain around 1760 and continued into the early 19th century, marking a significant shift from agrarian economies to industrialized and machine-manufacturing economies. ([britannica.com](https://www.britannica.com/event/Industrial-Revolution?utm_source=openai))

This period introduced several transformative changes to manufacturing practices:

1. **Mechanization of Production**: The introduction of machines like the spinning jenny and the power loom automated tasks previously performed by hand, significantly increasing production efficiency. ([britannica.com](https://www.britannica.com/event/Industrial-Revolution?utm_source=openai))

2. **Centralization in Factories**: Manufacturing shifted from decentralized home-based production to centralized factories, bringing workers together under one roof for better coordination and supervision. ([fiveable.me](https://fiveable.me/principles-management/unit-3/3-industrial-revolution/study-guide/kGTtqMKdsw9V9Jzn?utm_source=openai))

3. **Division of Labor and Specialization**: Work processes were broken down into simple, repetitive tasks, allowing workers to focus on specific parts of the production process, thereby increasing efficiency. ([fiveable.me](https://fiveable.me/principles-management/unit-3/3-industrial-revolution/study-guide/kGTtqMKdsw9V9Jzn?utm_source=openai))

4. **Standardization of Products**: The use of interchangeable parts and standardized processes led to uniformity in products, facilitating mass production and repair. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Industrialisation?utm_source=openai))

These innovations collectively transformed manufacturing, leading to increased productivity, the rise of factory-based economies, and significant social and economic changes.

Fisk patented the Fisk Metallic Burial Case, an airtight cast-iron coffin designed to preserve bodies during transportation. However, these early metal caskets were expensive and not widely adopted. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fisk_metallic_burial_case?utm_source=openai))

The industry saw significant growth in the early 20th century. Batesville Casket Company, founded in 1884, began producing metal caskets in 1918. By the mid-20th century, metal caskets became more prevalent, with companies like Aurora Casket Company transitioning to metal casket production in the 1940s. ([assemblymag.com](https://www.assemblymag.com/articles/87043-the-history-of-caskets?utm_source=openai))

By the 1950s, metal caskets accounted for more than one-third of the casket market, and this share continued to grow, reaching nearly two-thirds by the mid-1970s. ([cfsaa.org](https://www.cfsaa.org/casketindustry/?utm_source=openai)) This shift was driven by advancements in manufacturing processes, increased availability of materials, and changing consumer preferences.

Ancient Egypt (sarcophagi).search_query: When did Ancient Egypt begin and when were sarcophagi used?
Ancient Egypt (sarcophagi).evidence:
Ancient Egypt is generally considered to have begun around 3100 BCE, when Upper and Lower Egypt were unified under the first pharaoh, Menes. ([livescience.com](https://www.livescience.com/55578-egyptian-civilization.html?utm_source=openai))

The use of sarcophagi in Ancient Egypt dates back to the 3rd Dynasty (c. 2650–2575 BCE). Initially, these stone coffins were designed to resemble mud-brick palaces, reflecting the architectural style of the time. ([britannica.com](https://www.britannica.com/topic/sarcophagus?utm_source=openai))

Over time, the design and materials of sarcophagi evolved. By the 11th Dynasty (c. 2081–1991 BCE), box-like sarcophagi made of wood or limestone became common. During the 17th Dynasty (c. 1630–1540 BCE), anthropoid coffins—coffins shaped to resemble the human form—were introduced. These coffins were often made from materials such as wood, pottery, or stone, and in the case of royalty, sometimes from solid gold or silver. ([britannica.com](https://www.britannica.com/topic/sarcophagus?utm_source=openai))

The practice of enclosing inner coffins within stone outer sarcophagi continued into the Ptolemaic period (c. 305–30 BCE), reflecting the enduring significance of sarcophagi in Egyptian burial customs. ([britannica.com](https://www.britannica.com/topic/sarcophagus?utm_source=openai))

18th century (refinement, mahogany/oak/p.search_query: When did the 18th century occur and when did materials like mahogany become common in furniture?
