The 18th century spanned from January 1, 1701, to December 31, 1800. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/18th_century?utm_source=openai))

Mahogany began to gain prominence in furniture making during the early 18th century. While the wood was known in Europe since the 16th century, its widespread use in cabinetmaking accelerated after the British Parliament passed the Naval Stores Act in 1721, which removed import duties on timber from British colonies in the Americas. This legislation significantly boosted the mahogany trade, with imports into England reaching 525 tons per annum by 1740 and over 30,000 tons by 1788. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mahogany?utm_source=openai))

By the 1730s, mahogany had become the preferred material for high-quality furniture in Britain and its American colonies. Notable cabinetmakers like Thomas Chippendale utilized mahogany to craft elegant pieces that showcased the wood's durability and aesthetic appeal. ([paxtonhouse.co.uk](https://paxtonhouse.co.uk/mahogany-and-slavery/?utm_source=openai))

In France, the adoption of mahogany in furniture making began in the 1750s and 1760s, following the English example. Renowned cabinetmakers such as Jean-François Oeben and Jean-Henri Riesener incorporated mahogany into their designs, contributing to the Classical Revival in French furniture. ([sothebys.com](https://www.sothebys.com/en/articles/mahogany-and-the-master-cabinet-maker?utm_source=openai))

By the 1790s, mahogany was widely used in Europe and North America, becoming synonymous with fine furniture craftsmanship. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mahogany?utm_source=openai))

19th century (cast iron and lead-lined c.search_query: When did cast iron and lead-lined coffins appear in the 19th century?
19th century (cast iron and lead-lined c.evidence:
In the 19th century, cast iron and lead-lined coffins emerged as significant innovations in burial practices, primarily during the mid-1800s.

**Cast Iron Coffins:**

In 1848, Almond Dunbar Fisk patented the first cast iron coffin, known as the "Fisk Metallic Burial Case." These coffins were designed to be airtight and durable, aiming to preserve the body and deter grave robbers. They featured sculpted designs and glass viewing plates, allowing mourners to view the deceased without exposure to potential pathogens. Fisk's coffins gained popularity among wealthier families and were especially valued for transporting bodies over long distances without decomposition. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fisk_metallic_burial_case?utm_source=openai))

**Lead-Lined Coffins:**

Lead-lined coffins became prevalent in the late 19th century, particularly among the affluent. The lead lining provided an additional barrier against moisture and decay, ensuring the preservation of the body. These coffins were often elaborately designed, reflecting the status and wealth of the deceased. For instance, in the late 19th century, coffins for the wealthy were typically made of French-polished oak and often lead-lined, featuring solid cast brass handles. ([mola.org.uk](https://www.mola.org.uk/discoveries/news/park-street-and-coffin-industry?utm_source=openai))

Both cast iron and lead-lined coffins represented advancements in burial technology, emphasizing body preservation and the display of social status during the 19th century.

The Industrial Revolution is commonly recognized as beginning in Great Britain around 1760. This period marked a significant shift from agrarian economies to industrialized and mechanized systems, introducing innovations such as the steam engine and mechanized textile production. ([britannica.com](https://www.britannica.com/event/Industrial-Revolution?utm_source=openai))

However, some historians argue that the roots of industrialization trace back to the 17th century. Research indicates that during the reign of the Stuarts, Britain experienced a transition from an agricultural to a manufacturing-based economy, laying the groundwork for the Industrial Revolution. In the United States, the Industrial Revolution began in the late 18th and early 19th centuries, with significant developments in textile manufacturing and infrastructure, such as the construction of the Erie Canal between 1817 and 1821. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Industrial_Revolution_in_the_United_States?utm_source=openai))

20th century modern casket industry (mas.search_query: When did mass-produced metal caskets become common in the 20th century United States?
20th century modern casket industry (mas.evidence:
Mass-produced metal caskets became increasingly common in the United States during the early to mid-20th century. The Batesville Casket Company, founded in 1884, began manufacturing metal caskets in 1918, marking a significant shift in the industry. By the 1950s, Batesville and other manufacturers had established extensive sales networks, distributing metal caskets to funeral homes across North America. ([assemblymag.com](https://www.assemblymag.com/articles/87043-the-history-of-caskets?utm_source=openai))

Similarly, the Aurora Casket Company, established in 1890, transitioned to producing metal caskets in the 1940s. By 1954, Aurora had phased out wooden casket production, focusing exclusively on metal caskets. ([company-histories.com](https://www.company-histories.com/Aurora-Casket-Company-Inc-Company-History.html?utm_source=openai))

By the early 1950s, there were more than 700 casket manufacturers in the United States. However, after decades of consolidation, only 147 companies remained active in 2003. Today, less than a dozen manufacturers assemble more than 90 percent of all metal caskets sold in the United States. ([assemblymag.com](https://www.assemblymag.com/articles/87043-the-history-of-caskets?utm_source=openai))

The widespread adoption of mass-produced metal caskets in the mid-20th century was driven by advancements in manufacturing technology, increased demand for durable and protective burial options, and the consolidation of the casket manufacturing industry.

Contemporary biodegradable caskets (bamb.search_query: When did biodegradable/bamboo caskets become available and gain attention as a sustainable option?
Contemporary biodegradable caskets (bamb.evidence:
Biodegradable caskets, including those made from bamboo, have gained prominence as sustainable burial options over the past few decades. The concept of green burials, which emphasize the use of natural, biodegradable materials, has been around for centuries. However, the modern movement toward eco-friendly funerals began to take shape in the early 2000s.

In 2005, the Green Burial Council was established to promote environmentally responsible death care practices. This organization has played a significant role in certifying and promoting biodegradable caskets, including those made from bamboo. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sustainable_cemetery?utm_source=openai))

The increased awareness of environmental issues and the desire for sustainable practices have led to a growing interest in biodegradable caskets. Materials like bamboo, known for their rapid growth and renewability, have become popular choices. Companies such as Eco Casket Co. and Passages International have been offering bamboo caskets since the early 2000s, catering to the demand for eco-friendly funeral options. ([ecocasketco.com](https://ecocasketco.com/products/bamboo-biodegradable-casket?utm_source=openai))

In summary, while the use of biodegradable materials in burials has ancient roots, the modern adoption of bamboo caskets as a sustainable option began in the early 2000s, coinciding with the rise of the green burial movement and the establishment of organizations like the Green Burial Council.

sample_1.justification: The bundle references Starbucks' public goal to cut waste by 2030 (announced around 2019) and a 'Borrow a Cup' pilot that was publicized in 2020; a model needs knowledge through 2020 to cover both items without temporal leakage.

Starbucks waste-cut goal by 2030.search_query: When did Starbucks announce a goal to cut waste in half by 2030?
Starbucks waste-cut goal by 2030.evidence:
Starbucks announced its goal to reduce waste by 50% by 2030 on January 21, 2020. This commitment was part of a broader initiative to become a "resource-positive" company, aiming to store more carbon than it emits, eliminate waste, and provide more clean freshwater than it uses. ([stories.starbucks.com](https://stories.starbucks.com/emea/stories/2020/starbucks-announces-multi-decade-aspiration-to-become-resource-positive/?utm_source=openai))

To achieve this waste reduction target, Starbucks outlined several strategies, including expanding plant-based menu options, shifting away from single-use packaging, and investing in sustainable agricultural practices and waste management. ([stories.starbucks.com](https://stories.starbucks.com/emea/stories/2020/5-things-to-know-about-starbucks-new-environmental-sustainability-commitment?utm_source=openai))

In subsequent years, Starbucks has made significant progress toward this goal. By April 2023, the company had certified 3,508 Greener Stores globally, expanding the program to 20 markets. ([about.starbucks.com](https://about.starbucks.com/press/2023/starbucks-verifies-3500-greener-stores-globally/?utm_source=openai)) Additionally, in March 2024, Starbucks announced the certification of 6,091 Greener Stores worldwide, nearly doubling its portfolio in the past year. ([about.starbucks.com](https://about.starbucks.com/press/2024/starbucks-announces-6000-greener-stores-worldwide/?utm_source=openai))

These efforts reflect Starbucks' ongoing commitment to sustainability and its ambitious target of halving waste by 2030.

Starbucks 'Borrow a Cup' pilot.search_query: When did Starbucks pilot a 'Borrow a Cup' reusable cup program?
Starbucks 'Borrow a Cup' pilot.evidence:
Starbucks initiated its "Borrow a Cup" reusable cup program in March 2021 with a pilot in five Seattle stores. ([seattle.eater.com](https://seattle.eater.com/2021/4/7/22372019/starbucks-pilot-program-borrow-a-cup-starts-in-seattle?utm_source=openai)) This program allowed customers to order beverages in reusable cups, paying a $1 refundable deposit, and return them via contactless kiosks or through a local recycling service. ([vendingmarketwatch.com](https://www.vendingmarketwatch.com/coffee-service/news/21217887/starbuckss-borrow-a-cup-program-tests-in-seattle-charges-1-deposit?utm_source=openai)) The pilot ran until May 31, 2021. ([foodnetwork.com](https://www.foodnetwork.com/fn-dish/news/starbucks-reusable-cup-program-borrow-a-cup-seattle?utm_source=openai))

Following the Seattle trial, Starbucks expanded the program to other locations. In January 2022, the company launched the "Borrow a Cup" program in Singapore, operating across three stores from January to May 2022. ([stories.starbucks.com](https://stories.starbucks.com/asia/stories/2022/starbucks-launches-a-reusable-borrow-a-cup-program-at-three-stores-in-singapore/?utm_source=openai)) Additionally, in August 2023, Starbucks tested the program in 12 stores in Napa and Petaluma, California, running from August 14 through October 22, 2023. ([about.starbucks.com](https://about.starbucks.com/press/2023/starbucks-latest-california-borrow-a-cup-test-furthers-companys-shift-toward-reusables/?utm_source=openai))

These initiatives are part of Starbucks' broader commitment to sustainability, aiming to reduce waste by 50% by 2030. ([content-prod-live.cert.starbucks.com](https://content-prod-live.cert.starbucks.com/binary/v2/asset/137-83561.pdf?utm_source=openai))

Java Generics.search_query: When were generics introduced in Java (Java 5)?
Java Generics.evidence: Generics were introduced in Java with the release of J2SE 5.0 (Java 5) in 2004. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Generics_in_Java?utm_source=openai)) This addition allowed developers to write more flexible and reusable code while maintaining type safety. Prior to this, collections in Java used raw types, which required explicit casting and could lead to runtime errors. With generics, developers can specify the type of objects stored in collections, reducing the risk of `ClassCastException` and enhancing code reliability. ([docs.oracle.com](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/extra/generics/intro.html?utm_source=openai))

Java Collections Framework.search_query: When was the Java Collections Framework introduced (JDK 1.2)?
Java Collections Framework.evidence: The Java Collections Framework was introduced in JDK 1.2, released in 1998. ([cs.cmu.edu](https://www.cs.cmu.edu/~charlie/courses/17-214/2021-spring/slides/20210318-collections-design.pdf?utm_source=openai)) This framework provided a unified architecture for representing and manipulating collections, enabling developers to work with data structures more efficiently and consistently. ([docs.oracle.com](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/technotes/guides/collections/index.html?utm_source=openai))

Introduction of prominent bullet drop me.search_query: When did Call of Duty introduce the Blackout battle royale mode or notable bullet drop mechanics?
Introduction of prominent bullet drop me.evidence:
Call of Duty introduced the Blackout battle royale mode in **Call of Duty: Black Ops 4**, released on October 12, 2018. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Call_of_Duty%3A_Black_Ops_4?utm_source=openai)) This mode was the franchise's first venture into the battle royale genre, featuring a vast map with iconic locations from the Black Ops series.

Regarding bullet drop mechanics, **Call of Duty: Black Ops 4** incorporated this feature into its Blackout mode. In Blackout, bullets act as projectiles with travel time and drop-off over distance, requiring players to adjust their aim for long-range shots. This was a significant departure from the traditional hitscan mechanics used in other Call of Duty titles. ([dexerto.com](https://www.dexerto.com/call-of-duty/how-bullet-drop-works-call-duty-blackout-190359/?utm_source=openai))

Prior to Black Ops 4, the main series Call of Duty games did not feature bullet drop mechanics. However, the campaign of **Call of Duty 4: Modern Warfare**, released in 2007, included a mission where players had to account for bullet drop when sniping at long distances. This was a unique instance and not a standard mechanic in the multiplayer modes. ([dexerto.com](https://www.dexerto.com/call-of-duty/call-of-duty-dev-reveals-how-bullet-drop-will-work-modern-warfare-710625/?utm_source=openai))

In summary, Blackout introduced both the battle royale mode and notable bullet drop mechanics to the Call of Duty franchise in 2018.

CSS Flexible Box Layout Module Level 1 (.search_query: When did the CSS Flexible Box Layout Module Level 1 become a W3C Recommendation?
CSS Flexible Box Layout Module Level 1 (.evidence:
The CSS Flexible Box Layout Module Level 1, commonly known as Flexbox, has not yet been finalized as a W3C Recommendation. As of January 2026, the most recent publication is a Candidate Recommendation Draft dated October 14, 2025. This status indicates that the specification is stable and suitable for implementation, but it has not yet reached the final Recommendation stage. ([w3.org](https://www.w3.org/standards/history/css-flexbox-1/?utm_source=openai))

Flexbox was first introduced as a Working Draft on July 23, 2009. It progressed through various stages, including Last Call Working Drafts in 2014 and 2015, before reaching the Candidate Recommendation status on November 19, 2018. The most recent update, as mentioned, is the Candidate Recommendation Draft from October 14, 2025. ([w3.org](https://www.w3.org/standards/history/css-flexbox-1/?utm_source=openai))

While Flexbox has been widely implemented in modern browsers, it remains in the Candidate Recommendation phase, awaiting further review and potential finalization as a W3C Recommendation.

D3.js (Data-Driven Documents).evidence: D3.js, short for Data-Driven Documents, is a JavaScript library designed for creating dynamic, interactive data visualizations in web browsers. It was first released on February 18, 2011. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/D3.js?utm_source=openai))

HTML (original creation).evidence:
HTML (Hypertext Markup Language) was first introduced in 1991 by Tim Berners-Lee, a physicist at CERN (European Organization for Nuclear Research). He developed HTML as part of the World Wide Web project to enable researchers to share documents over the internet. The initial version of HTML comprised 18 elements, including the fundamental hyperlink tag, which allowed users to navigate between documents. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HTML?utm_source=openai))

In 1993, the Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF) began formalizing HTML, leading to the publication of the first official specification, HTML 2.0, in November 1995. This version standardized features like forms and tables, which were essential for web development at the time. ([loc.gov](https://www.loc.gov/preservation/digital/formats/fdd/fdd000476.shtml?utm_source=openai))

Since then, HTML has undergone several revisions to accommodate the evolving needs of web development, with significant updates such as HTML 4.01 in 1999 and HTML5 in 2014. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HTML?utm_source=openai))

HTML (original creation).evidence:
HTML (Hypertext Markup Language) was first introduced in 1991 by Tim Berners-Lee, a physicist at CERN (European Organization for Nuclear Research). He developed HTML as part of the World Wide Web project to enable researchers to share documents over the internet. The initial version of HTML comprised 18 elements, including basic tags for formatting text and creating hyperlinks. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HTML?utm_source=openai))

In 1993, the Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF) began formalizing HTML, leading to the publication of the first official specification, HTML 2.0, in November 1995. This version standardized features like forms and tables, which were essential for web development at the time. ([loc.gov](https://www.loc.gov/preservation/digital/formats/fdd/fdd000476.shtml?utm_source=openai))

Since then, HTML has undergone several revisions to accommodate the evolving needs of web development, with significant updates such as HTML 3.2 in 1997, HTML 4.01 in 1999, and HTML5 in 2014. ([w3resource.com](https://www.w3resource.com/html/HTML-versions.php?utm_source=openai))

Art Nouveau (movement start).search_query: When did the Art Nouveau movement begin?
Art Nouveau (movement start).evidence:
The Art Nouveau movement began in the early 1890s, with its first notable expressions in Brussels, Belgium. The Hôtel Tassel, designed by Victor Horta and completed in 1893, is often cited as one of the earliest examples of this style. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Art_Nouveau?utm_source=openai)) The movement quickly spread to other parts of Europe and the United States, reaching its peak around 1900. It was characterized by organic forms, sinuous lines, and a desire to unify art and design across various disciplines. ([magazine.artland.com](https://magazine.artland.com/art-movement-art-nouveau/?utm_source=openai))

Impressionism (movement start / first ex.search_query: When did Impressionism begin / when was the first Impressionist exhibition?
Impressionism (movement start / first ex.evidence:
Impressionism, a revolutionary art movement, began in the early 1870s in France. The first Impressionist exhibition took place on April 15, 1874, at 35 Boulevard des Capucines in Paris. This exhibition was organized by the Société anonyme des artistes peintres, sculpteurs, graveurs, etc., a group of artists who had been rejected by the official Paris Salon and sought to exhibit their works independently. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_Impressionist_Exhibition?utm_source=openai))

The exhibition featured 165 works by 30 artists, including Claude Monet, Pierre-Auguste Renoir, Edgar Degas, and Camille Pissarro. The term "Impressionism" was coined by art critic Louis Leroy in a satirical review titled "The Exhibition of the Impressionists," published on April 25, 1874, in the magazine *Le Charivari*. Leroy's use of the word "impression" was inspired by the title of Monet's painting *Impression, Sunrise*. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_Impressionist_Exhibition?utm_source=openai))

Despite facing criticism and commercial challenges, the Impressionists continued to hold exhibitions, with a total of eight between 1874 and 1886, solidifying their place in art history. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_Impressionist_Exhibition?utm_source=openai))

For a more detailed exploration of how Impressionism began, you might find this video informative:

[How Impressionism Began](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FfehaHSdpD0&utm_source=openai)

Surrealism (movement founding).search_query: When was Surrealism founded or established?
Surrealism (movement founding).evidence:
Surrealism was officially established in 1924 with the publication of the first Surrealist Manifesto by French poet and critic André Breton. This manifesto outlined the movement's goals, aiming to "resolve the previously contradictory conditions of dream and reality into an absolute reality, a super-reality," or surreality. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Surrealism?utm_source=openai))

The term "surrealism" was first coined by French poet Guillaume Apollinaire in 1917. He used it to describe his play "Les Mamelles de Tirésias," which he referred to as a "Drame surréaliste." ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Surrealism?utm_source=openai))

While Apollinaire introduced the term, it was Breton's 1924 manifesto that formally founded Surrealism as a cultural and artistic movement. The movement sought to express the unconscious mind, often resulting in illogical or dreamlike scenes and ideas. ([britannica.com](https://www.britannica.com/art/Surrealism?utm_source=openai))

Romanticism (movement start).search_query: When did the Romanticism movement begin?
Romanticism (movement start).evidence: Romanticism, an artistic and intellectual movement, began in the late 18th century, around the 1790s. In England, it is often marked by the 1798 publication of "Lyrical Ballads" by William Wordsworth and Samuel Taylor Coleridge, which emphasized emotion and nature over reason. ([britannica.com](https://www.britannica.com/art/Romanticism?utm_source=openai)) In Germany, the movement's early phase, known as Jena Romanticism, spanned from approximately 1798 to 1804, with figures like Friedrich Schlegel and Novalis contributing significantly. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jena_Romanticism?utm_source=openai)) In France, Romanticism gained prominence in the 1820s, with poets such as Lamartine and Hugo leading the way. Gothic (art/architecture emergence).search_query: When did Gothic art and architecture emerge?
Gothic (art/architecture emergence).evidence:
Gothic art and architecture emerged in the mid-12th century, around 1130–1140, in the Île-de-France region of northern France. The Abbey Church of Saint-Denis, rebuilt by Abbot Suger between 1135 and 1144, is often considered the first Gothic building. This period marked a significant departure from the preceding Romanesque style, introducing innovations such as the ribbed vault, pointed arch, and flying buttress, which allowed for higher ceilings and larger windows, filling interiors with light. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gothic_architecture?utm_source=openai))

The Gothic style rapidly spread across Europe, influencing architecture, sculpture, painting, and stained glass. By the late 14th century, it had evolved into the International Gothic style, characterized by a more secular and naturalistic approach, which continued until the late 15th century. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/French_art?utm_source=openai))

In summary, Gothic art and architecture began in the mid-12th century in northern France and flourished throughout Europe over the following centuries.

Steampunk (term/genre emergence).search_query: When did the term 'steampunk' originate or the genre emerge?
Steampunk (term/genre emergence).evidence:
The term "steampunk" was coined in 1987 by science fiction author K.W. Jeter. He used it in a letter to the magazine *Locus* to describe a wave of fantasy novels set in Victorian times and celebrating the technology of the era, much of which was powered by steam. ([merriam-webster.com](https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/steampunk?utm_source=openai))

While the term emerged in the late 1980s, the genre's roots trace back to earlier works. Authors like H.G. Wells and Jules Verne, writing in the late 19th century, created science fiction set in their own times that featured advanced technology powered by steam, such as flying machines and submarines. ([dictionary.com](https://www.dictionary.com/culture/pop-culture/steampunk?utm_source=openai))

In the 1960s and 1970s, several works now considered seminal to the genre were published. For instance, Michael Moorcock's 1971 novel *The Warlord of the Air* is often cited as an early example of steampunk literature. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steampunk?utm_source=openai))

Therefore, while the term "steampunk" was introduced in 1987, the genre's emergence can be traced back to earlier works that reimagined the 19th and early 20th centuries with futuristic technology and aesthetics.

Manga (modern emergence).search_query: When did modern manga as a distinct form begin?
Manga (modern emergence).evidence:
Modern manga, as a distinct form of Japanese comic art, began to take shape in the early 20th century. While the term "manga" was first used in the late 18th century, it referred to various forms of cartooning and did not specifically denote the sequential art form we recognize today. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_manga?utm_source=openai))

The evolution toward modern manga was significantly influenced by Western-style cartoons introduced to Japan in the late 19th century. These cartoons featured speech balloons and narrative sequences, elements that became integral to modern manga. In the 1920s, Japanese artists began adapting American comic strips, leading to the development of manga that closely resembled contemporary forms. Notably, some early examples of such manga were read from left to right, mirroring Western comics. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_manga?utm_source=openai))

A pivotal figure in this transformation was Rakuten Kitazawa (1876–1955), who is credited with using the term "manga" in its modern sense. His work in the early 20th century helped establish the foundation for the manga industry. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_manga?utm_source=openai))

The post-World War II era marked a significant turning point for manga. During the U.S. occupation of Japan (1945–1952), there was an influx of Western comics and animated films, which inspired Japanese artists. Osamu Tezuka, often referred to as the "godfather of manga," was particularly influential. His work, such as "Astro Boy" (1952), introduced cinematic techniques and complex narratives, setting new standards for character design, pacing, and emotional depth in manga. ([britannica.com](https://www.britannica.com/art/manga-Japanese-comics?utm_source=openai))

In summary, while the roots of manga trace back to earlier periods, modern manga as a distinct form began to emerge in the early 20th century, with significant developments occurring during the post-World War II era.

Medieval (period).search_query: What years define the Medieval period?
Medieval (period).evidence:
The Medieval period, also known as the Middle Ages, is traditionally defined as spanning from the 5th to the late 15th century. This era began with the fall of the Western Roman Empire in 476 CE and concluded with the onset of the Renaissance and the Age of Discovery. ([britannica.com](https://www.britannica.com/event/Middle-Ages?utm_source=openai))

Historians often divide the Middle Ages into three distinct phases:

1. **Early Middle Ages (c. 500–1000 CE):** Sometimes referred to as the "Dark Ages," this period was marked by the decline of urban centers and a decrease in cultural and economic activity following the fall of Rome.

2. **High Middle Ages (c. 1000–1300 CE):** Characterized by population growth, the rise of powerful kingdoms, and the establishment of universities, this era also saw the beginning of the Crusades.

3. **Late Middle Ages (c. 1300–1500 CE):** This phase experienced significant events such as the Black Death, the Hundred Years' War, and the fall of Constantinople in 1453, which collectively contributed to the transition into the Renaissance.

It's important to note that these dates are approximate, and different historians may propose varying timeframes based on regional developments and specific historical events.

Rococo (style emergence).search_query: When did the Rococo style emerge?
Rococo (style emergence).evidence:
The Rococo style emerged in France during the early 18th century, around the 1720s and 1730s, as a reaction against the grandeur and formalism of the Baroque period. It was characterized by elaborate ornamentation, asymmetrical designs, and the use of natural motifs such as shells, flowers, and foliage. ([britannica.com](https://www.britannica.com/art/Rococo?utm_source=openai))

The term "Rococo" is derived from the French word "rocaille," meaning "rock work," which referred to the shell-covered rock work used to decorate artificial grottoes. This style quickly spread beyond France, influencing regions like northern Italy, Austria, southern Germany, Central Europe, and Russia. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rococo?utm_source=openai))

In England, Rococo began to influence design in the 1730s, particularly in silverwork, porcelain, and furniture. The style flourished there between 1740 and 1770, with designers developing a distinctly British version of Rococo. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rococo?utm_source=openai))

In the United States, Rococo elements began to appear in the 1750s, primarily in decorative arts such as furniture and silverware. The style was introduced through imported objects and the influence of European-trained artisans. ([metmuseum.org](https://www.metmuseum.org/toah/hd/roco/hd_roco.htm?utm_source=openai))

Overall, Rococo was a significant artistic movement that emerged in the early 18th century and left a lasting impact on art and design across Europe and beyond.

Symbolism (movement start).search_query: When did Symbolism as an art movement begin?
Symbolism (movement start).evidence:
Symbolism emerged as a literary movement in France during the 1860s, with Charles Baudelaire's 1857 publication of *Les Fleurs du mal* being a significant precursor. The movement gained prominence in the 1880s, particularly following the 1886 publication of Jean Moréas's *Symbolist Manifesto* in *Le Figaro*, which formally defined the movement and distinguished it from related literary styles. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symbolism_%28movement%29?utm_source=openai))

In the visual arts, Symbolism began to take shape in the late 19th century, around the 1870s and 1880s. Artists like Gustave Moreau, Odilon Redon, and Pierre Puvis de Chavannes were among the early proponents, creating works that emphasized emotion, imagination, and spirituality over realistic representation. ([rem.routledge.com](https://www.rem.routledge.com/articles/overview/symbolism-overview?utm_source=openai))

Therefore, while the literary roots of Symbolism trace back to the 1860s, the movement as a cohesive artistic force began to coalesce in the 1870s and 1880s.

Baroque (period start).search_query: When did the Baroque period begin?
Baroque (period start).evidence:
The Baroque period began around 1600 in Rome, Italy. It emerged as a response to the Protestant Reformation, with the Catholic Church promoting this style to inspire awe and convey religious themes through art and architecture. The Baroque period is generally considered to have ended around 1750, transitioning into the Rococo style. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baroque?utm_source=openai))

Impressionism (movement start).search_query: When did Impressionism begin or when was the first Impressionist exhibition?
Impressionism (movement start).evidence:
Impressionism began in the early 1870s when a group of artists, including Claude Monet, Pierre-Auguste Renoir, Edgar Degas, and Camille Pissarro, sought to break away from traditional artistic conventions. They aimed to capture the fleeting effects of light and color in their works.

The first Impressionist exhibition took place on April 15, 1874, at 35 Boulevard des Capucines in Paris, in the studio of photographer Nadar. This exhibition marked the official debut of the movement, showcasing 165 works by 30 artists. The term "Impressionism" was coined by art critic Louis Leroy in a satirical review titled "The Exhibition of the Impressionists," published on April 25, 1874, in *Le Charivari*. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_Impressionist_Exhibition?utm_source=openai))

The exhibition was a commercial failure, with only about 3,500 visitors over its month-long run, compared to the 400,000 visitors to the official Salon of 1874. Despite this, the movement gained momentum, leading to seven more Impressionist exhibitions between 1876 and 1886. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_Impressionist_Exhibition?utm_source=openai))

In 2024, the Musée d'Orsay commemorated the 150th anniversary of this pivotal event with the exhibition "Paris 1874: Inventing Impressionism," featuring approximately 130 works that highlighted the significance of the first Impressionist exhibition. ([musee-orsay.fr](https://www.musee-orsay.fr/en/whats-on/exhibitions/paris-1874-inventing-impressionism?utm_source=openai))

Romanticism, an artistic and intellectual movement, began in Europe in the late 18th century, around the 1790s. It emerged as a reaction against the Enlightenment's emphasis on reason and the Industrial Revolution's focus on mechanization, advocating instead for emotion, individualism, and a deep appreciation of nature.

In England, Romanticism is often considered to have started with the publication of "Lyrical Ballads" in 1798 by William Wordsworth and Samuel Taylor Coleridge. Wordsworth's "Preface" to the second edition of this work in 1800, describing poetry as "the spontaneous overflow of powerful feelings," became a manifesto for the English Romantic movement. ([britannica.com](https://www.britannica.com/art/Romanticism?utm_source=openai))

In Germany, the first phase of Romanticism, known as Jena Romanticism, began around 1798 and was marked by innovations in both content and literary style, with a focus on the mystical and the subconscious. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jena_Romanticism?utm_source=openai))

In France, Romanticism gained prominence in the early 19th century, with key figures such as François-René de Chateaubriand and Madame de Staël contributing to its development. ([britannica.com](https://www.britannica.com/art/Romanticism?utm_source=openai))

Overall, while the exact starting point of Romanticism varied by country, the movement broadly began in the late 18th century and reached its peak in the first half of the 19th century.

By contrast, steampunk explored alternative histories where steam power remained dominant. ([dictionary.com](https://www.dictionary.com/culture/pop-culture/steampunk?utm_source=openai))

Since its inception, the term "steampunk" has been applied retroactively to earlier works that fit its themes, such as Michael Moorcock's 1971 novel *The Warlord of the Air*. ([steampunk-explorer.com](https://steampunk-explorer.com/articles/what-steampunk?utm_source=openai))

Manga (modern emergence).search_query: When did modern manga become distinct?
Manga (modern emergence).evidence:
Modern manga, as we recognize it today, began to take its distinct form in the post-World War II era, particularly during the 1950s. This period marked a significant transformation in Japanese comics, influenced by both domestic cultural developments and external factors.

Before World War II, Japan had a rich tradition of illustrated narratives, such as the 12th-century *Chōjū-jinbutsu-giga* scrolls and the 19th-century *Hokusai Manga* by Katsushika Hokusai. However, these works were not comics in the modern sense, as they lacked sequential storytelling and speech balloons. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_manga?utm_source=openai))

The term "manga" itself was first used in the late 18th century, but it referred to whimsical or impromptu pictures rather than the sequential art form we associate with the term today. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_manga?utm_source=openai))

The true emergence of modern manga began in the 1950s, during the American occupation of Japan. This era saw the introduction of Western comics and animated films, which inspired Japanese artists to develop their own style. A pivotal figure in this transformation was Osamu Tezuka, often referred to as the "God of Manga." Tezuka's work, such as *Astro Boy* (1952), incorporated elements from American cartoons, including large expressive eyes, and introduced dynamic storytelling techniques. ([britannica.com](https://www.britannica.com/art/manga-Japanese-comics?utm_source=openai))

The 1950s also witnessed the publication of the first magazine dedicated exclusively to manga, Kodansha's *Shonen Magazine*, which began in 1959. This development signified the growing popularity and commercialization of the medium. ([britannica.com](https://www.britannica.com/art/manga-Japanese-comics?utm_source=openai))

In summary, while Japan's artistic traditions laid the groundwork, it was in the 1950s, influenced by Western comics and the creative innovations of artists like Tezuka, that modern manga began to emerge as a distinct and influential form of entertainment.

Medieval (period).search_query: What years define the Medieval period?
Medieval (period).evidence:
The Medieval period, also known as the Middle Ages, is traditionally defined as spanning from the 5th to the late 15th century. This era began with the fall of the Western Roman Empire in 476 CE and concluded with the onset of the Renaissance and the Age of Discovery. ([britannica.com](https://www.britannica.com/event/Middle-Ages?utm_source=openai))

Historians often divide the Middle Ages into three distinct phases:

1. **Early Middle Ages (c. 500–1000 CE):** Sometimes referred to as the "Dark Ages," this period was marked by the decline of urban centers and a decrease in cultural and economic activity following the fall of Rome.

2. **High Middle Ages (c. 1000–1300 CE):** Characterized by population growth, the rise of powerful kingdoms, and the establishment of universities, this era saw significant developments in art, architecture, and learning.

3. **Late Middle Ages (c. 1300–1500 CE):** This phase experienced challenges such as the Black Death, the Hundred Years' War, and social upheaval, leading to profound changes in European society.

It's important to note that these dates are approximate, and the exact boundaries of the Medieval period can vary depending on regional histories and scholarly interpretations. ([britannica.com](https://www.britannica.com/topic/history-of-Europe/The-Middle-Ages?utm_source=openai))

Rococo (style emergence).evidence: Rococo emerged in France during the early 18th century, around the 1730s, as a reaction against the grandeur and strict regulations of Baroque art. It was characterized by ornate and decorative qualities, including light colors, asymmetrical designs, and playful themes. The movement often depicted scenes of love, nature, and frivolity, utilizing motifs such as shells, scrolls, and floral patterns. Rococo artists, including Jean-Antoine Watteau, François Boucher, and Jean-Honoré Fragonard, emphasized elegance and wit, often portraying aristocratic leisure and pastoral landscapes. Symbolism (movement start).search_query: When did Symbolism start as an art movement?
Symbolism (movement start).evidence:
Symbolism began as a literary movement in France during the 1860s, with Charles Baudelaire's 1857 publication of *Les Fleurs du mal* being a significant precursor. The movement gained prominence in the 1880s, particularly after the publication of Jean Moréas's *Symbolist Manifesto* in 1886, which formally defined the movement and distinguished it from naturalism and realism. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symbolism_%28movement%29?utm_source=openai))

In the visual arts, Symbolism emerged in the late 19th century, around the 1880s, as a reaction against the materialism and rationalism of the industrial age. Artists sought to express the ineffable and the metaphysical through visual art, using symbols and allegories to convey themes of dreams, mysticism, and the human psyche. ([arthistory.gg](https://www.arthistory.gg/movement/symbolism?utm_source=openai))

Therefore, while Symbolism's roots trace back to the 1860s, it formally began as an art movement in the 1880s.

The movement continued to evolve through eight exhibitions between 1874 and 1886, solidifying its place in art history. ([museumtv.art](https://www.museumtv.art/en/artnews/articles/what-is-impressionism-artistic-movement/?utm_source=openai))

For a visual overview of Impressionism, you might find this video helpful:

[What is Impressionism? Art Movements & Styles](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HTOO-ukvs4g&utm_source=openai)

Surrealism (movement founding).evidence:
Surrealism was officially founded in 1924 when French poet and critic André Breton published the first Surrealist Manifesto in Paris. ([britannica.com](https://www.britannica.com/art/Surrealism?utm_source=openai)) This manifesto outlined the movement's goals, aiming to reunite conscious and unconscious realms of experience to create an "absolute reality, a surreality." ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Surrealism?utm_source=openai))

The term "surrealism" was first coined by French poet Guillaume Apollinaire in 1917. He used it to describe his play "Les Mamelles de Tirésias," which he referred to as a "Drame surréaliste." ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Surrealism?utm_source=openai)) However, it was Breton's 1924 manifesto that formally established Surrealism as a distinct cultural and artistic movement.

Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood (founding).search_query: When was the Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood founded?
Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood (founding).evidence: The Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood was founded in 1848 by seven young British artists: painters Dante Gabriel Rossetti, William Holman Hunt, and John Everett Millais; painters James Collinson and Frederic George Stephens; sculptor Thomas Woolner; and critic William Michael Rossetti. ([britannica.com](https://www.britannica.com/art/Pre-Raphaelite-Brotherhood?utm_source=openai)) They convened at Millais's family home on Gower Street in London, aiming to challenge the academic norms of the Royal Academy and to revive the artistic styles and values of early Italian art, particularly that of the 14th and 15th centuries. ([fitzmuseum.cam.ac.uk](https://fitzmuseum.cam.ac.uk/explore-our-collection/highlights/context/tradition-and-change/the-pre-raphaelite-brotherhood?utm_source=openai))

Romanticism (movement start).evidence: Romanticism, an artistic and intellectual movement, began in the late 18th century, around the 1790s. In England, it is often marked by the 1798 publication of *Lyrical Ballads* by William Wordsworth and Samuel Taylor Coleridge, which emphasized emotion and nature over reason. ([britannica.com](https://www.britannica.com/art/Romanticism?utm_source=openai)) In Germany, the movement's early phase, known as Jena Romanticism, spanned from approximately 1798 to 1804, with key figures like Friedrich Schlegel and Novalis. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jena_Romanticism?utm_source=openai)) In France, Romanticism gained prominence in the 1820s, with writers such as Victor Hugo and painters like Eugène Delacroix leading the movement. ([britannica.com](https://www.britannica.com/topic/history-of-Europe/General-character-of-the-Romantic-movement?utm_source=openai)) Thus, while Romanticism's origins trace back to the 1790s, its influence expanded and evolved throughout the 19th century across Europe.

Gothic (art/architecture emergence).evidence: Gothic art and architecture emerged in the early 12th century, around 1130, in the Île-de-France region of northern France. The Abbey Church of Saint-Denis, rebuilt under Abbot Suger between 1135 and 1144, is often cited as the first Gothic building. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gothic_architecture?utm_source=openai)) This innovative style rapidly spread across Europe, evolving into the International Gothic style by the late 14th century and continuing until the late 15th century. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gothic_art?utm_source=openai))

Steampunk (term/genre emergence).evidence:
The term "steampunk" was coined in 1987 by science fiction author K.W. Jeter. He used it in a letter to the science fiction magazine *Locus* to describe a wave of fantasy novels set in Victorian times and celebrating the technology of the era, much of which was powered by steam. ([merriam-webster.com](https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/steampunk?utm_source=openai))

Jeter's coining of "steampunk" was a tongue-in-cheek variant of "cyberpunk," a genre that emerged around the same time and focused on futuristic, computer-based technology. By contrast, steampunk explored alternative histories where steam power remained dominant. ([dictionary.com](https://www.dictionary.com/culture/pop-culture/steampunk?utm_source=openai))

Since its inception, the term "steampunk" has been applied retroactively to earlier works, such as Michael Moorcock's 1971 novel *The Warlord of the Air*, which is considered a precursor to the genre. ([steampunk-explorer.com](https://steampunk-explorer.com/articles/what-steampunk?utm_source=openai))

Manga (modern emergence).evidence:
Modern manga, as we recognize it today, began to take shape in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. The term "manga" was first used in the late 18th century, but it wasn't until the Meiji period (1868–1912) that the medium started to resemble contemporary comics. During this era, Japanese artists began incorporating Western artistic styles and storytelling methods, leading to the development of modern manga. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_manga?utm_source=openai))

A pivotal figure in this transformation was Rakuten Kitazawa, who is often credited as one of the first modern manga artists. His work, characterized by playful characters and humorous storylines, helped establish manga as a mainstream medium in Japan. ([toonsmag.com](https://www.toonsmag.com/origins-of-manga-and-anime-a-cultural-phenomenon/?utm_source=openai))

The post-World War II era marked a significant expansion in the popularity and diversity of manga. Artists like Osamu Tezuka revolutionized the medium by introducing cinematic storytelling techniques and more complex narratives. Tezuka's work, especially the epic series "Astro Boy," set standards for character design, pacing, and emotional depth, solidifying manga's place in Japanese culture. ([mexicohistorico.com](https://www.mexicohistorico.com/paginas/japanese-comics-a-cultural-phenomenon-in-japan-3f2f71b0.html?utm_source=openai))

Therefore, while the roots of manga trace back to earlier periods, the emergence of modern manga as a distinct and influential art form began in the late 19th century and evolved significantly in the mid-20th century.

Medieval (period).search_query: What years define the Medieval period?
Medieval (period).evidence:
The Medieval period, also known as the Middle Ages, is traditionally defined as spanning from the 5th to the late 15th century. It began with the fall of the Western Roman Empire in 476 CE and concluded with the onset of the Renaissance and the Age of Discovery. ([britannica.com](https://www.britannica.com/event/Middle-Ages?utm_source=openai))

Historians often divide the Middle Ages into three distinct phases:

1. **Early Middle Ages (c. 500–1000 CE):** This period, sometimes referred to as the "Dark Ages," was marked by the decline of urban centers and a decrease in trade and cultural activity following the fall of Rome.

2. **High Middle Ages (c. 1000–1300 CE):** Characterized by population growth, the rise of powerful kingdoms, and the establishment of universities, this era saw significant cultural and intellectual developments.

3. **Late Middle Ages (c. 1300–1500 CE):** This phase experienced challenges such as the Black Death, the Hundred Years' War, and social upheavals, leading to significant transformations in European society.

It's important to note that these dates are approximate, and the exact boundaries of the Medieval period can vary depending on regional histories and scholarly interpretations.

Rococo (style emergence).evidence:
Rococo emerged in France during the early 18th century, around the 1730s, as a reaction against the grandeur and strict regulations of Baroque art. It was characterized by ornate and decorative qualities, including light colors, asymmetrical designs, and playful themes. The movement often depicted scenes of love, nature, and frivolity, utilizing motifs such as shells, scrolls, and floral patterns. Rococo artists, including Jean-Antoine Watteau, François Boucher, and Jean-Honoré Fragonard, emphasized elegance and wit, often portraying aristocratic leisure and pastoral landscapes. ([arthistory.gg](https://www.arthistory.gg/movement/rococo?utm_source=openai))

The term "rococo" is derived from the French word "rocaille," which refers to a form of colorful and irregular rockwork used to embellish grottoes and fountains. This term was later used to describe the style's intricate and refined ornamentation. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rococo_Revival?utm_source=openai))

Rococo's influence extended beyond painting to architecture, interior design, and decorative arts, notably in the opulent interiors of European palaces. The movement flourished in France between the 1730s and 1760s, and its influence spread to other parts of Europe, including Italy, Austria, Germany, and Russia. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rococo?utm_source=openai))

Symbolism (movement start).evidence:
Symbolism began in the late 19th century, emerging as a literary movement in France during the 1880s. The term "Symbolism" was first used by the poet Jean Moréas in his 1886 manifesto published in Le Figaro, where he outlined the movement's principles and objectives. ([nationalgalleries.org](https://www.nationalgalleries.org/art-and-artists/glossary-terms/symbolism?utm_source=openai))

The movement sought to express individual emotional experience through the subtle and suggestive use of highly symbolized language, reacting against the rationalism and materialism that had come to dominate Western European culture. ([britannica.com](https://www.britannica.com/art/Symbolism-literary-and-artistic-movement?utm_source=openai))

While it originated in literature, Symbolism also influenced visual arts, theater, and music, spreading throughout Europe and impacting various artistic disciplines. ([britannica.com](https://www.britannica.com/art/Symbolism-literary-and-artistic-movement?utm_source=openai))

Baroque (period start).search_query: When did the Baroque period begin?
Baroque (period start).evidence:
The Baroque period began around 1600 in Rome, Italy. It emerged as a response to the Protestant Reformation, with the Catholic Church promoting this style to inspire awe and convey religious themes more effectively. The Baroque style is characterized by grandeur, sensuous richness, drama, vitality, movement, tension, emotional exuberance, and a tendency to blur distinctions between the various arts. ([britannica.com](https://www.britannica.com/art/Baroque-art-and-architecture?utm_source=openai))

The term "Baroque" is believed to have originated from the Portuguese word "barroco," meaning "a flawed pearl," reflecting the style's ornate and elaborate nature. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baroque?utm_source=openai))

The Baroque period continued until the mid-18th century, evolving into the Rococo style by the 1730s. In regions like Spain and Portugal, the Baroque style persisted until the early 19th century. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baroque?utm_source=openai))

For a visual overview of the Baroque period, you might find this video helpful:

[What was the Baroque period? - Summary | Definition, Characteristics, and Representatives.](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TQaTH4bT_Qg&utm_source=openai)

Victorian (era start).search_query: When did the Victorian era begin?
Victorian (era start).evidence: The Victorian era began on June 20, 1837, with the accession of Queen Victoria to the British throne, and ended on January 22, 1901, upon her death. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Victorian_era?utm_source=openai)) This period is characterized by significant social, cultural, and technological changes in the United Kingdom.

Starbucks waste-cut goal by 2030.search_query: When did Starbucks announce its goal to cut waste in half by 2030?
Starbucks waste-cut goal by 2030.evidence:
Starbucks announced its goal to reduce waste by 50% by 2030 on January 21, 2020. This commitment was part of a broader initiative to become a "resource-positive" company, aiming to store more carbon than it emits, eliminate waste, and provide more clean freshwater than it uses. ([stories.starbucks.com](https://stories.starbucks.com/emea/stories/2020/starbucks-announces-multi-decade-aspiration-to-become-resource-positive/?utm_source=openai))

To achieve this waste reduction target, Starbucks outlined several strategies, including expanding plant-based menu options, shifting away from single-use packaging, and investing in sustainable farming and forest practices. ([foodbusinessnews.net](https://www.foodbusinessnews.net/articles/15257-starbucks-lays-out-2030-sustainability-targets?utm_source=openai))

In subsequent years, Starbucks has made significant progress toward these goals. By March 2024, the company had certified 6,091 Greener Stores across more than 40 markets globally, nearly doubling its portfolio in the past year. ([about.starbucks.com](https://about.starbucks.com/press/2024/starbucks-announces-6000-greener-stores-worldwide/?utm_source=openai)) Additionally, in April 2024, Starbucks introduced redesigned cold cups that use up to 20% less plastic, aiming to eliminate over 13.5 million pounds of plastic waste annually. ([apnews.com](https://apnews.com/article/90f19ce6ff721c7bf900f1447932dcc0?utm_source=openai))


## Starbucks' Sustainability Initiatives and Progress:
- [Starbucks reusable cups now accepted at drive-thru, mobile orders](https://www.axios.com/2024/01/03/starbucks-reusable-cup-policy-mobile-drive-thru?utm_source=openai), Published on Wednesday, January 03
- [Booming cold drink sales mean more plastic waste. So Starbucks redesigned its cups](https://apnews.com/article/90f19ce6ff721c7bf900f1447932dcc0?utm_source=openai), Published on Thursday, April 18
- [Citing sustainability, Starbucks wants to overhaul its iconic cup. Will customers go along?](https://apnews.com/article/5a3a5d7d4a66725f9747cbab23cb586d?utm_source=openai), Published on Thursday, September 14

Starbucks 'Borrow a Cup' pilot.search_query: When did Starbucks start testing the 'Borrow a Cup' reusable cup program?
Starbucks 'Borrow a Cup' pilot.evidence:
Starbucks initiated its "Borrow a Cup" program in March 2021 with a pilot in five Seattle stores. ([seattle.eater.com](https://seattle.eater.com/2021/4/7/22372019/starbucks-pilot-program-borrow-a-cup-starts-in-seattle?utm_source=openai)) This program allowed customers to borrow reusable cups for a $1 refundable deposit, aiming to reduce single-use cup waste. The pilot ran until May 31, 2021. ([foodnetwork.com](https://www.foodnetwork.com/fn-dish/news/starbucks-reusable-cup-program-borrow-a-cup-seattle?utm_source=openai))

Following the success of the Seattle pilot, Starbucks expanded the program to other locations. In January 2022, the company launched the "Borrow a Cup" program in Singapore, offering reusable cups at three stores from January to May 2022. ([stories.starbucks.com](https://stories.starbucks.com/asia/stories/2022/starbucks-launches-a-reusable-borrow-a-cup-program-at-three-stores-in-singapore/?utm_source=openai)) By August 2023, Starbucks had extended the program to 12 stores in Napa and Petaluma, California, furthering its commitment to sustainability. ([about.starbucks.com](https://about.starbucks.com/press/2023/starbucks-latest-california-borrow-a-cup-test-furthers-companys-shift-toward-reusables/?utm_source=openai))

These initiatives are part of Starbucks' broader goal to reduce waste and promote the use of reusable cups across its global operations.

Bullet drop prominence in Call of Duty (.evidence:
Bullet drop mechanics were introduced in Call of Duty's battle royale modes with the release of Blackout in 2018. Blender Geometry Nodes (feature introduc.search_query: When were Geometry Nodes introduced in Blender (which version and year)?
Blender Geometry Nodes (feature introduc.evidence:
Geometry Nodes were introduced in Blender 2.92, released in February 2021. ([help.meriloft.com](https://help.meriloft.com/blender/getting_started/about/history.html?utm_source=openai)) This initial implementation focused on object scattering and instancing, laying the foundation for a node-based procedural modeling system. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blender_%28software%29?utm_source=openai))

In subsequent releases, Geometry Nodes were expanded to include more advanced features. Blender 2.93, released in June 2021, introduced additional nodes for mesh primitives and advanced scattering, enhancing procedural modeling capabilities. ([uploads3.craft.co](https://uploads3.craft.co/uploads/operating_source/document/1034654/96557504af330529.pdf?utm_source=openai)) Later, Blender 3.0, released in December 2021, overhauled the Geometry Nodes workflow with the introduction of the 'Fields' system, making the system more intuitive and similar to shader nodes. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blender_%28software%29?utm_source=openai))

For a visual introduction to Geometry Nodes in Blender 3.0, you might find the following tutorial helpful:

Geometry Nodes nodes used (Point Distrib.search_query: When were Point Distribute, Point Instance, Attribute Randomize, and Align Rotation to Vector nodes available in Blender Geometry Nodes?
Geometry Nodes nodes used (Point Distrib.evidence:
Blender's Geometry Nodes introduced several key nodes in its early versions:

- **Point Distribute**: Introduced in Blender 2.92, this node places points on the surface of the input geometry. ([docs.blender.org](https://docs.blender.org/manual/en/2.92/modeling/geometry_nodes/point/point_distribute.html?utm_source=openai))

- **Point Instance**: Also added in Blender 2.92, this node allows for instancing objects on points. ([developer.blender.org](https://developer.blender.org/docs/release_notes/2.92/geometry_nodes/?utm_source=openai))

- **Attribute Randomize**: This node was part of the initial release in Blender 2.92, enabling randomization of attributes. ([developer.blender.org](https://developer.blender.org/docs/release_notes/2.92/geometry_nodes/?utm_source=openai))

- **Align Rotation to Vector**: Introduced in Blender 2.92, this node aligns the rotation of points to a specified vector. ([developer.blender.org](https://developer.blender.org/docs/release_notes/2.92/geometry_nodes/?utm_source=openai))

These nodes were foundational in the development of Geometry Nodes, facilitating object scattering, instancing, and attribute manipulation.

Starbucks waste-cut goal by 2030.evidence:
Starbucks announced its goal to cut waste in half by 2030 on January 21, 2020. This commitment was part of a broader initiative to become a "resource-positive" company, aiming to store more carbon than it emits, eliminate waste, and provide more clean freshwater than it uses. ([stories.starbucks.com](https://stories.starbucks.com/emea/stories/2020/starbucks-announces-multi-decade-aspiration-to-become-resource-positive/?utm_source=openai))

To achieve this target, Starbucks set specific objectives, including a 50% reduction in waste sent to landfills from stores and manufacturing by 2030, using a 2018 baseline. ([foodbusinessnews.net](https://www.foodbusinessnews.net/articles/15257-starbucks-lays-out-2030-sustainability-targets?utm_source=openai)) The company also planned to shift away from single-use packaging that ends up in landfills and expand plant-based menu options to promote a more environmentally friendly menu. ([stories.starbucks.com](https://stories.starbucks.com/emea/stories/2020/starbucks-announces-multi-decade-aspiration-to-become-resource-positive/?utm_source=openai))

In March 2023, Starbucks announced over $50 million in planned investments to advance its sustainability targets, including the goal to cut its waste footprint in half by 2030. ([about.starbucks.com](https://about.starbucks.com/press/2023/starbucks-commits-over-50-million-to-sustainable-waste-and-water-funds-toward-a-resource-positive-future/?utm_source=openai))

Starbucks 'Borrow a Cup' pilot.search_query: When was Starbucks testing a 'Borrow a Cup' reusable cup program?
Starbucks 'Borrow a Cup' pilot.evidence:
Starbucks initiated its "Borrow a Cup" reusable cup program in March 2021, testing it at five Seattle locations. ([seattle.eater.com](https://seattle.eater.com/2021/4/7/22372019/starbucks-pilot-program-borrow-a-cup-starts-in-seattle?utm_source=openai)) The program allowed customers to pay a $1 refundable deposit for a reusable cup, which they could return at designated kiosks or through a local recycling service. This initiative aimed to reduce single-use cup waste and was part of Starbucks' broader commitment to sustainability. ([vendingmarketwatch.com](https://www.vendingmarketwatch.com/coffee-service/news/21217887/starbuckss-borrow-a-cup-program-tests-in-seattle-charges-1-deposit?utm_source=openai))

Building on this initial test, Starbucks expanded the program in August 2023 to 12 stores in Napa and Petaluma, California. Customers had the option to bring their own personal cup, borrow a cup from Starbucks, or choose a "For Here Ware" ceramic or glass cup for in-store use. This expansion was part of Starbucks' goal to make all customer packaging reusable, recyclable, or compostable in the future. ([about.starbucks.com](https://about.starbucks.com/press/2023/starbucks-latest-california-borrow-a-cup-test-furthers-companys-shift-toward-reusables/?utm_source=openai))

These tests are part of Starbucks' ongoing efforts to reduce waste and promote sustainability in its operations.

Introduction of bullet drop in Call of D.search_query: When did bullet drop become a notable mechanic in Call of Duty (e.g., in Blackout or later titles)?
Introduction of bullet drop in Call of D.evidence:
Bullet drop, the phenomenon where a projectile's trajectory curves downward due to gravity, was first introduced as a notable mechanic in the Call of Duty series with the release of **Call of Duty: Black Ops 4** in 2018. In this installment, the Blackout mode incorporated bullet drop to enhance realism, requiring players to adjust their aim for long-range shots. ([dexerto.com](https://www.dexerto.com/call-of-duty/how-bullet-drop-works-call-duty-blackout-190359/?utm_source=openai))

Prior to Black Ops 4, Call of Duty games utilized a hitscan mechanic, where bullets traveled instantaneously in a straight line to the target, without accounting for travel time or drop. This approach was prevalent in earlier titles, including the original Modern Warfare series. ([dexerto.com](https://www.dexerto.com/call-of-duty/call-of-duty-dev-reveals-how-bullet-drop-will-work-modern-warfare-710625/?utm_source=openai))

The introduction of bullet drop in Black Ops 4 was part of a broader effort to introduce more realistic ballistics into the game. This change was further expanded upon in **Call of Duty: Modern Warfare** (2019), where bullet drop and other ballistic factors were integrated into both the campaign and multiplayer modes, marking a significant shift from the traditional hitscan mechanics. ([dexerto.com](https://www.dexerto.com/call-of-duty/call-of-duty-dev-reveals-how-bullet-drop-will-work-modern-warfare-710625/?utm_source=openai))

In summary, bullet drop became a notable mechanic in Call of Duty starting with Black Ops 4's Blackout mode in 2018, and its influence has continued in subsequent titles, contributing to a more immersive and realistic shooting experience.

The viewport meta tag, introduced by Apple with the iPhone in 2007, was pivotal for RWD. It allowed web pages to control their rendering on mobile devices, ensuring content fit the screen appropriately. Without this tag, mobile browsers would render pages at a default width, often requiring users to zoom in or out. ([pdfarchive.kunaldawn.com](https://pdfarchive.kunaldawn.com/archive/computer_engineering/Responsive_Web_Design_with_HTML5_and_CSS_-_Ben_Frain.pdf?utm_source=openai))

By 2013, responsive web design had gained significant traction, with Mashable declaring it the "Year of Responsive Web Design." ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Responsive_web_design?utm_source=openai)) The viewport meta tag became a standard practice for mobile optimization, ensuring consistent and user-friendly experiences across various devices.

CSS Animations (@keyframes) support/spec.search_query: When were CSS animations and @keyframes introduced or standardized?
CSS Animations (@keyframes) support/spec.evidence:
CSS animations, including the `@keyframes` rule, were introduced as part of the CSS3 specification. The initial working draft for CSS Animations was published by the W3C on March 20, 2009. ([w3.org](https://www.w3.org/TR/2009/WD-css3-animations-20090320/?utm_source=openai)) This draft outlined the concepts and syntax for defining animations using keyframes in CSS.

The `@keyframes` rule allows developers to specify intermediate steps in an animation sequence, enabling more complex and detailed animations directly within CSS. This approach provides greater control over animations compared to traditional CSS transitions, which are limited to changes between two states.

Browser support for CSS animations began to emerge around 2010. For instance, WebKit-based browsers like Safari and Chrome started implementing support for CSS animations and the `@keyframes` rule around that time. By June 2011, Firefox 5 included support for CSS animations. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CSS_animations?utm_source=openai)) Over the following years, support expanded to other major browsers, solidifying CSS animations as a standard feature for web development.

document.querySelector / querySelectorAl.search_query: When was document.querySelector / querySelectorAll introduced in browsers (Selectors API)?
document.querySelector / querySelectorAl.evidence:
The `document.querySelector()` and `document.querySelectorAll()` methods were introduced as part of the Selectors API, which was specified by the W3C. These methods allow developers to select DOM elements using CSS selectors, providing a more versatile approach compared to traditional methods like `getElementById()`.

The Selectors API was specified by the W3C in March 2009 as a "Last Call Working Draft," indicating that the specification was nearing completion at that time. ([fr.wikipedia.org](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Selectors_API?utm_source=openai))

In terms of browser support, the methods were implemented in various browsers around the following times:

- **Safari**: Version 3.1
- **Google Chrome**: Version 1.0
- **Internet Explorer**: Version 8 (only in standards mode)
- **Mozilla Firefox**: Version 3.1 beta

This widespread adoption has made `querySelector()` and `querySelectorAll()` standard tools for DOM manipulation in modern web development.

([techcrunch.com](https://techcrunch.com/2011/08/19/twitter-releases-bootstrap-a-set-of-tools-to-build-web-apps-using-css/?utm_source=openai)) It was developed by Mark Otto and Jacob Thornton at Twitter to provide a consistent framework for internal tools. Initially known as Twitter Blueprint, it was renamed to Bootstrap and made open-source on that date. ([bootstrap.rtlcss.com](https://bootstrap.rtlcss.com/docs/3.3/about/?utm_source=openai))

Starbucks waste-cut goal by 2030.search_query: When did Starbucks announce its goal to cut waste in half by 2030?
Starbucks waste-cut goal by 2030.evidence:
Starbucks announced its goal to reduce waste by 50% by 2030 on January 21, 2020. This commitment was part of a broader initiative to become a "resource-positive" company, aiming to store more carbon than it emits, eliminate waste, and provide more clean freshwater than it uses. ([stories.starbucks.com](https://stories.starbucks.com/emea/stories/2020/starbucks-announces-multi-decade-aspiration-to-become-resource-positive/?utm_source=openai))

To achieve this waste reduction target, Starbucks outlined several strategies, including expanding plant-based menu options, shifting away from single-use packaging, and investing in sustainable farming and forest practices. ([foodbusinessnews.net](https://www.foodbusinessnews.net/articles/15257-starbucks-lays-out-2030-sustainability-targets?utm_source=openai))

In subsequent years, Starbucks has made significant progress toward these goals. By April 2023, the company had certified 3,508 Greener Stores globally, expanding the program to 20 markets. ([about.starbucks.com](https://about.starbucks.com/press/2023/starbucks-verifies-3500-greener-stores-globally/?utm_source=openai)) Additionally, in March 2024, Starbucks announced the certification of 6,091 Greener Stores worldwide, nearly doubling its portfolio in the past year. ([about.starbucks.com](https://about.starbucks.com/press/2024/starbucks-announces-6000-greener-stores-worldwide/?utm_source=openai))

These efforts reflect Starbucks' ongoing commitment to sustainability and its ambitious targets for 2030.

Starbucks 'Borrow a Cup' pilot.search_query: When was Starbucks 'Borrow a Cup' reusable cup pilot announced or tested?
Starbucks 'Borrow a Cup' pilot.evidence:
Starbucks introduced its "Borrow a Cup" reusable cup pilot program in Seattle on March 30, 2021. This initiative allowed customers to borrow a reusable cup for a $1 refundable deposit, with the option to return it at participating store kiosks or through a local recycling service called Ridwell. ([foodnetwork.com](https://www.foodnetwork.com/fn-dish/news/starbucks-reusable-cup-program-borrow-a-cup-seattle?utm_source=openai))

Following the Seattle pilot, Starbucks expanded the program to other locations:

- **Singapore**: Launched on January 9, 2022, across three stores in the National University of Singapore, running until May 2022. ([stories.starbucks.com](https://stories.starbucks.com/asia/stories/2022/starbucks-launches-a-reusable-borrow-a-cup-program-at-three-stores-in-singapore/?utm_source=openai))

- **Taiwan**: Initiated in late July 2022 at two stores in Houshanpi and Taoyuan, with plans to expand to 60 stores by the end of 2023. ([stories.starbucks.com](https://stories.starbucks.com/asia/stories/2022/starbucks-offers-borrow-a-cup-program-at-sixty-stores-in-taiwan/?utm_source=openai))

- **California, USA**: From August 14 to October 22, 2023, Starbucks tested the program in 12 stores in Napa and Petaluma, offering customers the option to bring their own cup, borrow a cup from Starbucks, or choose a reusable ceramic or glass cup for in-store use. ([about.starbucks.com](https://about.starbucks.com/press/2023/starbucks-latest-california-borrow-a-cup-test-furthers-companys-shift-toward-reusables/?utm_source=openai))

These initiatives are part of Starbucks' broader commitment to sustainability and reducing single-use cup waste.

Introduction of bullet drop in Call of D.search_query: When did bullet drop or similar long-range ballistics become notable in Call of Duty modes (e.g., Blackout/modern titles)?
Introduction of bullet drop in Call of D.evidence:
Bullet drop and similar long-range ballistics mechanics were notably introduced in Call of Duty with the release of **Black Ops 4** in 2018. In this installment, Treyarch implemented a new ballistics system in the **Blackout** battle royale mode, where bullets behave as projectiles with travel time and drop-off over distance. This departure from the traditional hitscan mechanics required players to lead shots and adjust their aim to account for bullet drop, especially in long-range engagements. ([dexerto.com](https://www.dexerto.com/call-of-duty/how-bullet-drop-works-call-duty-blackout-190359/?utm_source=openai))

The inclusion of bullet drop in Blackout was a significant shift in Call of Duty's gameplay, as previous titles primarily utilized hitscan mechanics, where bullets hit targets instantly without considering travel time or drop. This change added a layer of realism and strategy to long-range combat, aligning Call of Duty more closely with other shooters that feature projectile-based ballistics systems. ([dexerto.com](https://www.dexerto.com/call-of-duty/call-of-duty-dev-reveals-how-bullet-drop-will-work-modern-warfare-710625/?utm_source=openai))

Following Black Ops 4, the 2019 release of **Call of Duty: Modern Warfare** further expanded on this concept. Infinity Ward introduced a more realistic ballistics system across all game modes, including the campaign, multiplayer, and co-op, where bullets have travel time and drop, requiring players to account for these factors in their aim and shooting strategy. ([dexerto.com](https://www.dexerto.com/call-of-duty/call-of-duty-dev-reveals-how-bullet-drop-will-work-modern-warfare-710625/?utm_source=openai))

In summary, bullet drop and long-range ballistics mechanics became prominent in Call of Duty starting with Black Ops 4 in 2018, marking a significant evolution in the series' approach to shooting mechanics.

For a detailed breakdown of bullet drop mechanics in Blackout, you might find this video helpful:

[Bullet Drop for ALL Guns in Blackout! (+ Extended Barrel & Suppressor Breakdown)](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ToOj0OP9D3Y&utm_source=openai)

The book also presented the famous Fibonacci sequence, which he introduced through a problem involving the growth of a rabbit population. ([britannica.com](https://www.britannica.com/topic/Liber-abaci?utm_source=openai))

A revised edition of "Liber Abaci" was published in 1228, dedicated to Michael Scot. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liber_Abaci?utm_source=openai))

Vigenère cipher first described / relate.search_query: When was the Vigenère cipher (or related Bellaso/Vigenère ciphers) first described?
Vigenère cipher first described / relate.evidence:
The Vigenère cipher, a method of encrypting alphabetic text, was first described by Italian cryptologist Giovan Battista Bellaso in his 1553 book *La cifra del Sig. Giovan Battista Bellaso*. Bellaso's cipher built upon the tabula recta introduced by Johannes Trithemius in 1508, adding a repeating key to switch cipher alphabets for each letter. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vigen%C3%A8re_cipher?utm_source=openai))

In 1586, French cryptographer Blaise de Vigenère published a similar cipher in his work *Traicté des chiffres ou secrètes manières d'escrire*. Due to this publication, the cipher became misattributed to Vigenère and is now commonly known as the Vigenère cipher. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blaise_de_Vigen%C3%A8re?utm_source=openai))

For centuries, the Vigenère cipher was considered unbreakable, earning the nickname "le chiffrage indéchiffrable" (the indecipherable cipher). It wasn't until 1863 that Friedrich Kasiski published a general method for deciphering Vigenère ciphers, revealing its vulnerabilities. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vigen%C3%A8re_cipher?utm_source=openai))

Vigenère cipher first described / relate.search_query: When was the Vigenère cipher (or related Bellaso/Vigenère ciphers) first described?
Vigenère cipher first described / relate.evidence:
The Vigenère cipher, a form of polyalphabetic substitution cipher, was first described by Italian cryptographer Giovan Battista Bellaso in 1553. ([britannica.com](https://www.britannica.com/topic/Vigenere-cipher?utm_source=openai)) Bellaso's method utilized a repeating key to shift letters in the plaintext, enhancing security over simple substitution ciphers.

In 1586, French cryptographer Blaise de Vigenère introduced a similar cipher, known as the autokey cipher, which used the plaintext itself as the key, further strengthening the encryption. ([britannica.com](https://www.britannica.com/topic/Vigenere-cipher?utm_source=openai)) Despite this, the cipher now known as the Vigenère cipher was based on Bellaso's original method.

For centuries, the Vigenère cipher was considered unbreakable, earning the nickname "le chiffrage indéchiffrable." It wasn't until 1863 that Friedrich Kasiski published a general method for deciphering it, marking a significant advancement in cryptanalysis. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vigen%C3%A8re_cipher?utm_source=openai))
