Fibonacci's "Liber Abaci" (Latin for "The Book of Calculation") was first published in 1202. This seminal work introduced the Hindu-Arabic numeral system to Europe, replacing the Roman numeral system and significantly advancing European mathematics. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liber_Abaci?utm_source=openai))

In "Liber Abaci," Fibonacci presented the sequence now known as the Fibonacci sequence, which he introduced through a problem involving the growth of a rabbit population. This sequence has since become a fundamental concept in mathematics. ([britannica.com](https://www.britannica.com/topic/Liber-abaci?utm_source=openai))

A revised edition of "Liber Abaci," dedicated to Michael Scot, was published in 1228. The original 1202 manuscript has not survived, but the 1228 version remains influential in the history of mathematics. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liber_Abaci?utm_source=openai))

Vigenère cipher first described / relate.search_query: When was the Vigenère cipher (or related Bellaso/Vigenère ciphers) first described?
Vigenère cipher first described / relate.evidence:
The Vigenère cipher, a polyalphabetic substitution cipher, was first described by Italian cryptographer Giovan Battista Bellaso in 1553. He introduced this method in his book *La cifra del Sig. Giovan Battista Bellaso*. ([britannica.com](https://www.britannica.com/topic/Vigenere-cipher?utm_source=openai))

The cipher gained its name from Blaise de Vigenère, a French diplomat and cryptographer, who in 1586 published a similar cipher in his work *Traicté des chiffres ou secrètes manières d'escrire*. Although Vigenère's cipher was distinct, it was often misattributed to him, leading to the association of his name with the cipher. ([britannica.com](https://www.britannica.com/topic/Vigenere-cipher?utm_source=openai))

The Vigenère cipher remained unbroken for centuries, earning the nickname "le chiffrage indéchiffrable" (the indecipherable cipher). It wasn't until 1863 that Friedrich Kasiski published a method to decipher it, marking a significant advancement in cryptanalysis. ([britannica.com](https://www.britannica.com/topic/Vigenere-cipher?utm_source=openai))

Starbucks waste-cut goal by 2030.search_query: When did Starbucks announce a goal to cut waste in half by 2030?
Starbucks waste-cut goal by 2030.evidence:
Starbucks announced its goal to reduce waste by 50% by 2030 on January 21, 2020. This commitment was part of a broader initiative to become a "resource-positive" company, aiming to store more carbon than it emits, eliminate waste, and provide more clean freshwater than it uses. ([stories.starbucks.com](https://stories.starbucks.com/emea/stories/2020/starbucks-announces-multi-decade-aspiration-to-become-resource-positive/?utm_source=openai))

To achieve this waste reduction target, Starbucks outlined several strategies, including expanding plant-based menu options, shifting away from single-use packaging, and investing in sustainable farming and forest practices. ([stories.starbucks.com](https://stories.starbucks.com/emea/stories/2020/5-things-to-know-about-starbucks-new-environmental-sustainability-commitment?utm_source=openai))

In subsequent years, Starbucks has taken significant steps toward this goal. By April 2023, the company had certified 3,508 Greener Stores globally, expanding the program to 20 markets. ([about.starbucks.com](https://about.starbucks.com/press/2023/starbucks-verifies-3500-greener-stores-globally/?utm_source=openai)) Additionally, in March 2024, Starbucks announced the verification of 6,091 Greener Stores worldwide, nearly doubling its portfolio in the past year. ([about.starbucks.com](https://about.starbucks.com/press/2024/starbucks-announces-6000-greener-stores-worldwide/?utm_source=openai))

These initiatives reflect Starbucks' ongoing commitment to sustainability and its ambitious target of halving waste by 2030.

Starbucks 'Borrow a Cup' pilot.search_query: When did Starbucks test a 'Borrow a Cup' reusable cup program or pilot?
Starbucks 'Borrow a Cup' pilot.evidence:
Starbucks initiated its "Borrow a Cup" reusable cup program in March 2021, testing it in five Seattle stores. ([seattle.eater.com](https://seattle.eater.com/2021/4/7/22372019/starbucks-pilot-program-borrow-a-cup-starts-in-seattle?utm_source=openai)) The program allowed customers to order beverages in reusable cups, paying a $1 refundable deposit, and return them via contactless kiosks or through a local recycling service. ([vendingmarketwatch.com](https://www.vendingmarketwatch.com/coffee-service/news/21217887/starbuckss-borrow-a-cup-program-tests-in-seattle-charges-1-deposit?utm_source=openai))

Building on this, Starbucks expanded the program to 12 stores in Napa and Petaluma, California, from August 14 to October 22, 2023. ([about.starbucks.com](https://about.starbucks.com/press/2023/starbucks-latest-california-borrow-a-cup-test-furthers-companys-shift-toward-reusables/?utm_source=openai)) This expansion aimed to further the company's commitment to reducing waste and promoting sustainability.

Additionally, Starbucks launched the "Borrow a Cup" program in Singapore across three stores in the National University of Singapore from January to May 2022. ([stories.starbucks.com](https://stories.starbucks.com/asia/stories/2022/starbucks-launches-a-reusable-borrow-a-cup-program-at-three-stores-in-singapore/?utm_source=openai)) The program has also been implemented in other regions, including Taiwan, where it was introduced in 60 stores in November 2022. ([stories.starbucks.com](https://stories.starbucks.com/asia/stories/2022/starbucks-offers-borrow-a-cup-program-at-sixty-stores-in-taiwan/?utm_source=openai))

These initiatives reflect Starbucks' ongoing efforts to reduce single-use cup waste and promote sustainable practices globally.

([about.starbucks.com](https://about.starbucks.com/press/2023/starbucks-latest-california-borrow-a-cup-test-furthers-companys-shift-toward-reusables/?utm_source=openai))

These initiatives are part of Starbucks' broader commitment to sustainability and reducing single-use cup waste.

Starbucks waste-cut goal by 2030.search_query: When did Starbucks announce its goal to cut waste in half by 2030?
Starbucks waste-cut goal by 2030.evidence:
Starbucks announced its goal to reduce waste by 50% by 2030 on January 21, 2020. This commitment was part of a broader initiative to become a "resource-positive" company, aiming to store more carbon than it emits, eliminate waste, and provide more clean freshwater than it uses. ([stories.starbucks.com](https://stories.starbucks.com/emea/stories/2020/starbucks-announces-multi-decade-aspiration-to-become-resource-positive/?utm_source=openai))

To achieve this waste reduction target, Starbucks has implemented several strategies, including expanding plant-based menu options, shifting away from single-use packaging, and investing in sustainable farming and forest practices. ([foodbusinessnews.net](https://www.foodbusinessnews.net/articles/15257-starbucks-lays-out-2030-sustainability-targets?utm_source=openai))

In March 2024, Starbucks furthered its environmental commitment by verifying 6,091 Greener Stores across more than 40 markets globally. These stores meet standards in areas such as water stewardship, energy efficiency, and waste diversion, contributing to the company's goal of reducing waste sent to landfills by 50% by 2030. ([about.starbucks.com](https://about.starbucks.com/press/2024/starbucks-announces-6000-greener-stores-worldwide/?utm_source=openai))

Additionally, in April 2024, Starbucks introduced redesigned cold cups that use up to 20% less plastic. This initiative is expected to eliminate over 13.5 million pounds of plastic waste annually and is part of the company's broader effort to reduce reliance on single-use plastics. ([apnews.com](https://apnews.com/article/90f19ce6ff721c7bf900f1447932dcc0?utm_source=openai))

Starbucks 'Borrow a Cup' pilot.search_query: When did Starbucks pilot or test a 'Borrow a Cup' reusable cup program?
Starbucks 'Borrow a Cup' pilot.evidence:
Starbucks initiated its "Borrow a Cup" reusable cup program with a pilot in five Seattle stores in April 2021. ([vendingmarketwatch.com](https://www.vendingmarketwatch.com/coffee-service/news/21217887/starbuckss-borrow-a-cup-program-tests-in-seattle-charges-1-deposit?utm_source=openai)) Customers could order beverages in reusable cups for a $1 refundable deposit, with the cups returned via contactless kiosks or through a local recycling service. The program aimed to reduce single-use cup waste and promote sustainability.

Following the Seattle trial, Starbucks expanded the "Borrow a Cup" program to other locations:

- **Singapore**: Launched in January 2022 across three stores in the National University of Singapore, running until May 2022. ([stories.starbucks.com](https://stories.starbucks.com/asia/stories/2022/starbucks-launches-a-reusable-borrow-a-cup-program-at-three-stores-in-singapore/?utm_source=openai))

- **California**: A test was conducted from August 14 to October 22, 2023, in 12 stores in Napa and Petaluma, offering customers the option to bring their own cup, borrow a cup from Starbucks, or use a reusable ceramic or glass cup for in-store consumption. ([about.starbucks.com](https://about.starbucks.com/press/2023/starbucks-latest-california-borrow-a-cup-test-furthers-companys-shift-toward-reusables/?utm_source=openai))

These initiatives are part of Starbucks' broader commitment to reducing waste and promoting sustainable practices.

For a visual overview of the "Borrow a Cup" program, you can watch the following video:

[New Test: Borrow a Cup, Save a Cup](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3Pn4UTaXNGw&utm_source=openai)

([cs.cmu.edu](https://www.cs.cmu.edu/~charlie/courses/17-214/2021-spring/slides/20210318-collections-design.pdf?utm_source=openai)) It was designed and developed primarily by Joshua Bloch. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Java_collections_framework?utm_source=openai)) This framework provided a unified architecture for representing and manipulating collections, enabling developers to work with data structures more efficiently and consistently. Introduction of bullet drop prominence i.search_query: When did bullet drop or similar long-range ballistics become prominent in Call of Duty modes like Blackout?
Introduction of bullet drop prominence i.evidence:
Bullet drop mechanics were introduced in Call of Duty's Blackout mode, which debuted in 2018 as part of Call of Duty: Black Ops 4. Prior to this, the series primarily utilized hitscan mechanics, where bullets traveled instantly to their target without considering travel time or drop. ([callofduty.fandom.com](https://callofduty.fandom.com/wiki/Hitscan?utm_source=openai))

In Blackout, bullets behave as projectiles, exhibiting travel time and drop-off over distance. This means that at longer ranges, players must account for bullet trajectory by leading shots and aiming higher to compensate for the downward curve of the bullet. ([dexerto.com](https://www.dexerto.com/call-of-duty/how-bullet-drop-works-call-duty-blackout-190359/?utm_source=openai))

The introduction of bullet drop in Blackout was part of a broader trend in the gaming industry to incorporate more realistic ballistics mechanics. For instance, the Battlefield series has long featured bullet drop and travel time, adding depth to long-range combat. ([battlefield.fandom.com](https://battlefield.fandom.com/wiki/Projectile_mechanics?utm_source=openai))

In summary, bullet drop became prominent in Call of Duty with the release of Blackout in 2018, marking a significant shift from the series' traditional hitscan mechanics to a more realistic projectile-based system.
